story: Close up of a young baby crocodile (Image: Jeremy HoldenFFI)Stunning images released for the first time show the small scaled creatures - barely the size of a human palm - in their first few months.The three clutches of eggs were hatched at a breeding ground in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, which is run by FFI and the Cambodian Forestry Administration.The wild population of Siamese crocodiles is estimated at an alarming 250 mature iniduals, which inhabit the remote mountains of the south-east Asian country.They are classed as critically endangered on the International Union for Conservation of Nature 'Red List'.                HEARTBREAKING video shows baby elephant WITHOUT his trunk                Photographer captures &lsquoone-in-a-million&rsquo shot of Emperor penguin wi...The species was actually believed to be extinct in the wild until it was rediscovered during a survey led by FFI.Around 99 per cent of their natural habitat has disappeared, mainly due rice farming and other agricultural activity.But the near-extinction of the reptiles has been caused by an explosion in hunting for their skins.Dr Jackson Frachette, who manages the breeding programme, said: This is the culmination of 18 years of hard work by FFI and our partners to protect and restore Siamese crocodiles in this part of Cambodia.A juvenile Siamese  crocodile being released (Image: Jeremy HoldenFFI)Siamese Crocodile at Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Centre (Image: Jeremy HoldenFFI)We've really built on that solid foundation and it feels as though we've turned a corner in our efforts to bring this species back from the brink.All 65 of the baby crocs will be reared in captivity for up to three years until they grow to one metre in length.They will then be big enough to fend for themselves and be released into protected areas.FFI is aiming to double to wild population of Siamese crocodiles by 2020.

story: The Labour&nbspMP told Brexit minister Dominic Raab he had been told Mrs May&rsquos proposals were &ldquodead in the water by EU negotiator Michel Barnier.When pushed on more information, he said he had been told &ldquoles propositions song mortes, which translates as &ldquothe proposals are dead.However the EU has quickly dismissed the accusation, saying a recorded transcript will prove Mr Barnier said nothing of the sort.Asked about the comments last night, European Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas said people should wait for the official transcript of Monday's behind-closed-doors meeting.                'PIE IN THE SKY!' John Major CONDEMNS Brexit in fiery outburst                 Top Tory in FURIOUS Brexit rant: &lsquoEU is holding UK PRISONER'He said rather than dismiss Chequers as dead, Mr Barnier had actually raised several &ldquopositive elements.Regarding the &ldquodead jibe, he said Mr Barnier said nothing of the sort and the official minutes would show this.Mr Schinas said: &ldquoMichel Barnier was very clear expressing the Commission position on Chequers from the very first moment.I don't think that people present in the room and beyond the room have any doubt on what we said on Chequers.Brexit news: The EU has dismissed Stephen Kinnock's Brexit claims (Image: )&ldquoWe identified where there were positive elements and we discussed also the possibility for further discussions to address issues that still create problems.He added that the private meeting provided the perfect recipe for everybody coming out of there and saying what one or the other understood Michel saying.Mr Schinas said: Let's wait for the transcript and then let's check the sort of things that are reported of what Michel Barnier said against what he actually really said.But relations again soured yesterday when Mr Raab and Mr Barnier appeared to have a fiery confrontation during talks in Brussels.Brexit news: The EU has dismissed claims Mr Barnier said Chequers was 'dead' (Image: )Brussels sources said the pair clashed over the border issue at a highly-charged meeting in Brussels and that Mr Barnier was &ldquoabsolutely furious.Progress on the Irish border issue since then has been &ldquoclose to zero, they said.Mr Barnier has repeatedly rejected UK proposal for avoiding a hard border such as using technology and exemptions to create an invisible border or a &ldquodual tariff customs partnership.Senior EU officials have dismissed both suggestions as &ldquomagical thinking and &ldquounicorns.

title: UK foreign aid amount latest update India Phil Campion
story: The Department for International Development said the UK will transfer &pound52million in aid to India&nbspthis year, and &pound46million in 201920 as part of an aid budget which now costs &pound13.4billion a year.Despite 230million people living in abject poverty, India is now rich enough to be able to afford to splurge &pound95.4million on a lunar probe called Chandrayaan-2, which is expected to launch later this year.Speaking on Sky News&rsquo The Pledge, ex-SAS soldier Phil Campion delivered a passionate speech in which he outlined why he saw the amount of aid India receives as necessary.He said: &ldquoThe UK&rsquos Department for International Development works in deprived areas of the world to make sure aid money reaches people who need it.                The law says we must spend, so spend we do, says DAVID DAVIES                Crazy to send foreign aid to a country such as India - EXPRESS COMMENT&ldquoNow I don&rsquot have a drama with giving aid to people who are suffering, especially if we had a hand in their misery.&ldquoHowever, the decision to give &pound98 million pounds with of aid to a country that has a nuclear programme, a space programme and a thriving movie industry is insane.He continued: &ldquoYes, you heard me right, India has all of the above, not to mention that it gives out more than &pound650 million pounds in aid than it receives.&ldquoHave we all gone mad? We have an NHS on its knees. All over, frontline services struggling to cope. Former servicemen are homeless and injured.Phil Campion asked why the UK still gave so much in aid to India, which has its on space programme  (Image: Sky News &bull Getty )&ldquoWhoever is sanctioning this lunacy is having a long hard look at what is going on around them.&ldquoWhat happened to charity begins at home? I know some amazing things I could do with &pound98 million, and it doesn&rsquot include lobbing other country&rsquos satellites up in the air for them.Although there is no suggestion British taxpayers&rsquo money will be used to fund the lunar probe, MPs have received stinging criticism in their constituencies for the foreign aid budget.David Davies, Tory MP for Monmouth, said this week: &ldquoThe Indians don&rsquot want or need our money. In effect, we are sponsoring an Indian Moon launch.India is a net donor of foreign aid, providing more assistance than it receives.In 201516 it gave away &pound912million in aid but received &pound254million from overseas countries and global banks.Chandrayaan-2 aims to demonstrate its growing technical abilities by landing a six-wheeled rover on the surface of the Moon &ndash a mission seen by many as a direct challenge to China&rsquos space ambitions.But furious MPs have questioned why taxpayers&rsquo cash is being funnelled to a fully-functioning democracy developing a growing aid programme of its own and pumping money into neighbours such as Bhutan, Afghanistan and Sri Lanka.The Department for International Development said &ldquotraditional financial aid to India had ended and it now worked in partnership with other departments to deliver joint economic development priorities.However, it confirmed the &pound98million it planned to send to India was taxpayers&rsquo money that would &ldquohelp stimulate prosperity, generate jobs, develop skills and open up new markets for both countries.

title: Brexit news latest EU UK Theresa May today Chequers no deal second vote
story: Non-party campaign group UK Unity took to the streets of London to make sure the 17.4 million Britons who voted for Brexit get a complete departure from the European Union.&nbspFurious Brexiteer protesters shouted &ldquowe want Brexit while holding placards stating &ldquoTreason May out now.Footage from RT shows one man shout: &ldquoWhat do we want? Theresa May out. Out traitor.He blasted: &ldquoWhat do we want?                Rachel Johnson backs Boris to deliver Brexit people voted forIn response, the rest of the protesters chanted: &ldquoOut, out, outMrs May&rsquos Brexit plan, calling for close regulatory alignment with the EU&rsquos single market for British exports, is a firm push towards a soft Brexit.The proposal includes plans to create a common rule book &ndash involving a free trade area with the EU on industrial and agricultural goods.Both Remainers and Brexiteers have ridiculed the Chequers proposal, with Remainer Tory MP Justin Greening claiming it is hated more than poll tax.Brexit news: Protests took place in London against the Chequers proposal (Image: )Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson, who resigned from his ministerial position in protest against Chequers, suggested the proposal would give Britain ' two-thirds of a diddly squat and the result in the inevitable outcome of victory for the EU.The brutal comments, made in Mr Johnson&rsquos column in The Daily , is likely to fuel speculation the former Foreign Secretary could be about to challenge Mrs May for the Tory Party leadership.Mr Johnson wrote: &ldquoIn adopting the Chequers proposals, we have gone into battle with the white flag fluttering over our leading tank.&ldquoIf we continue on this basis we will throw away most of the advantages of Brexit.Mrs May's spokesman hit back and said: &ldquoBoris Johnson resigned over Chequers. There are no new ideas in this article to respond to. What we need at this time is serious leadership with a serious plan and that's exactly what the country has with this Prime Minister and this Brexit plan.The EU&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier has also rejected Mrs May&rsquos plans, labelling them as &ldquoillegal, insane and impractical.Mr Barnier ruled out any special economic relationship with the UK and warned that to do so would unravel the entire &ldquoEuropean project.Mr Barnier said: &ldquoThey could stay in the single market, like Norway, which is also not a member of the EU, but they would then have to accept all the regulations and make contributions to European solidarity.But if we let the British cherrypick which of our regulations to follow, that would have serious consequence: all sorts of other third countries could insist that we offer them the same deal.

story: Brussels sources said the pair clashed over the border issue at a highly-charged meeting in Brussels and that Mr Barnier was &ldquoabsolutely furious.The angry exchanges came last month when Mr Raab and Mr Barnier met for the just the second time, the insiders said.Progress on the Irish border issue since then has been &ldquoclose to zero, they said.Mr Barnier has repeatedly rejected UK proposal for avoiding a hard border such as using technology and exemptions to create an invisible border or a &ldquodual tariff customs partnership.                Livid Leave voter fears Brexit will NEVER happen for THIS reason                 BREXIT BLOCK: Tory and Labour moderates to launch centrist allianceSenior EU officials have dismissed both suggestions as &ldquomagical thinking and &ldquounicorns.Mr Raab attended a further two-hour meeting in Brussels yesterday but left without holding the customary joint press conference with Mr Barnier.EU sources said there had been no conference &ldquobecause there wasn&rsquot much more to say.Sir Ivan Rogers, the former UK ambassador to Brussels, warned in a speech in Dublin last night that the risk of an &ldquoaccidental no deal was rising as both sides continued to talk past each other.Take a look back at all of today's Brexit news with Express's blog updates below:Leo Varadkar has denied Ireland is making plans for border checkpoints in the event of no deal (Image: PA)9.20pm: Ireland denies preparing for no-deal Brexit border checksLeo Varadkar has insisted his government is not making preparations for customs checkpoints on the border between the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland.His denial came after reports emerged this week Revenue Commissioners in Ireland were devising plans for full border checks amid fears of a no-deal Brexit.He said: The direction we've given to Revenue is not to prepare for customs posts on the land border between Ireland and Northern Ireland because that's something we're not contemplating.He added: If the Revenue Commissioners are in any way trying to put in any physical infrastructure then that is news to me and I really don't believe that's happening.                Irish Eurocrat tells Brexiteers to &lsquoSHUT UP&rsquo in ferocious EU outburstBill Clinton has warned Brexit is causing uncertainty in Ireland (Image: PA)7.50pm: &lsquoBrexit is causing uncertainty in Ireland&rsquoBill Clinton has weighed in on the Brexit debate during a visit to Dublin, saying the UK&rsquos orce from Europe is hindering the restoration of Northern Ireland&rsquos devolved government.The former US president said politicians should &ldquotake a breath and keep working towards reinstating a government at Stormont.Northern Ireland has been without a government for nearly two years following a row between Sinn Fein and the DUP over a failed green energy scheme.Speaking at Dublin Castle today, Mr Clinton said: If you were a Northern Irish politician you probably wouldn't want to go into Government either if you didn't know the details of Brexit and how it will affect Northern Ireland or how it will affect the relationship between Northern Ireland and the Republic, because how would you know what the terms of the agreement would be.There are still cranes up in Belfast and nobody wants to go back to the bad old days, so I think everybody should take a deep breath, and keep working.If people are smart enough to realise that you didn't have to have a document that would solve every problem, that would permit some solutions to emerge.The most important thing to me is that the Irish peace process and the work of Concern is rooted in both our common humanity and our notion of what I call inclusive tribalism.Ireland's Leo Varadkar has said a Brexit deal must be concluded by November 'at the latest' (Image:  IMAGES)6pm: EU in crisis: Bloc at risk of &lsquodeconstruction&rsquoThe European Union is at risk of being crushed under the weight of its own bureaucracy, French Senate G&eacuterard Larcher has warned.Mr Larcher said Brussels needs to urgently &ldquoreinvent itself and deal with existential issues facing the bloc including the migrant crisis which has sown ision across member states.The conservative politician accused the EU of being out of touch with the concerns of citizens in countries like Italy which has seen some 650,000 migrants land on its shores since 2014.READ MORE: EU IN CRISIS: French leader says Brussels being &lsquoCRUSHED&rsquo by its own bureaucracy4.20pm: Ireland issues November Brexit deal ultimatumA withdrawal agreement detailing the UK&rsquos orce terms with the EU must be concluded by November &ldquoat the latest, Irish leader Leo Varadkar has said.The Irish border issue is the last remaining hurdle negotiators from the UK and EU are working to overcome but a solution has yet to be reached.Brussels has proposed a backstop arrangement which would see Northern Ireland remain in the customs union and large parts of the single market.The backstop would kick in if no other terms are reached to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland the Irish Republic.But Downing Street has dismissed the EU&rsquos terms, saying it would lead to the breakup of the UK.Mr Varadkar told reporters: Our objective is to conclude a withdrawal agreement, including an Irish protocol between now and October or November at the latest.Ms Merkel and Mr Macron are meeting in Marseille to discuss issues facing the EU including Brexit (Image: REUTERS)Chancellor Philip Hammond is hoping to persuade EU finance leaders to support the Chequers deal (Image: EPA)4.10pm: Macron and Merkel arrive ahead for Marseille meetingFrench leader Emmanuel Macron is preparing to meet with his German counterpart Angela Merkel ahead of a major EU summit later this month.The pair are expected to focus on the bloc&rsquos ongoing issues with migration and the single currency are also likely to address the ongoing Brexit negotiations.3.10pm: &lsquoBrexit deal is in everyone&rsquos interests&rsquoChancellor Philip Hammond has arrived in Vienna to update fellow EU finance ministers on the UK&rsquos Brexit plans and attempt to sell the Chequers deal.&nbspHeading into the talks in the Austrian capital, the Chancellor said he would also be working to convince his EU counterparts to persuade the European Commission &ldquoto engage with us.He added: I believe we will be able to get a deal. It's very much in the interests of the EU27 as well as the UK that Brexit runs smoothly next March.Remember, this event is happening just eight to nine weeks before the European parliamentary elections.&ldquoIt's not in anybody's interest to have a chaotic Brexit, a Brexit without a deal, so we will keep working very hard together and I'm sure we will get there.Harvey Gavin taking over from Simon Osborne on live reporting.Brexit news: Dominic Raab and Michel Barnier are said to have clashed over Northern Ireland (Image: )                Pound euro exchange rate: GBP muted as Hammond warns of no-deal Brexit12.33 update: British negotiators make shock admission during talksBritain&rsquos Brexit negotiators have told their European Union counterparts Theresa May&rsquos Chequers proposals would not give the UK a competitive trade advantage over Europe.The astonishing admission came as the UK team tried to convince Brussels the Prime Ministers much-maligned blueprint was workable despite coming under fire from all sides.Michel Barnier, the EU&rsquos chief negotiator, has rejected the Chequers plan &ndash partly because he believes plans to sign up to only some single market rules would give it a competitive advantage.Britain has taken the bizarre position of arguing that this is not the case.The move has sparked outrage among hardline Tory Brexiteers and anti-Brexit campaigners alike.Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable said he will stay at the party's helm to fight Brexit (Image: EPA)11.34 update: Cable to stay on as Lib Dem leader to fight BrexitLiberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable has announced plans to step down after Brexit is resolved or stopped.Sir Vince, 75, said reports of his imminent departure were very wide of the mark and insisted he would stay on to steer the party through any Brexit-related turmoil, including any possible general election.However, in a London speech he said the time would be right for a leadership election after that under new rules he unveiled to widen participation in the party.He said: Reports I have read of my imminent departure are very wide of the mark.Now is not the time for an internal election, there is serious work for me and the party to do.Once Brexit is resolved or stopped, that will be the time to conduct a leadership election under the new rules.BBC presenter Andrew Neil warned of a 'considerable backlash' if a second Brexit vote was held (Image:  IMAGES)10.31 update: Andrew Neil warns against second referendum &ldquobacklashPolitical commentator Andrew Neil has warned of a considerable backlash against pro-Remain politicians if a new Brexit referendum was held.The BBC presenter said calls for a new vote have added huge uncertainty on an already unclear situation.Remainers such as Tory rebel Anna Soubry and Labour Lord Adonis, have joined forces to pressure Theresa May into holding a fresh vote on the terms of withdrawal.But Mr Neil said: There&rsquos been a lot of Remainers saying &lsquohey, we could re-open this again. We can litigate this again and maybe have another referendum.&rsquo It&rsquos added huge uncertainty that those who want another referendum &ndash and I understand the case for it &ndash they need to be careful.I think a lot of British people will think &lsquohey, for the first time we voted in a way the establishment didn&rsquot like and now the establishment wants us to vote again?&rsquo The backlash to that could be considerable.Brexit talks get under way in Brussels (Image: AFP)                Brexiteers take to streets of London to protest against May's Brexit                'How are you FUNDED?' Remain activist WALKS OUT and does not come back10.20am update: EU officials &ldquocould man British portsEuropean Union customs officials could be posted at British ports as a way to solve the Northern Ireland border issue.The suggestion is expected to be included among a raft of Brexit blueprints from the Tory Eurosceptic group led by influential Conservatives Steve Baker and Jacob Rees Mogg who have promised alternatives to Theresa May&rsquos Chequers proposals.Under the idea, EU staff would be allowed to monitor goods at ports such as Liverpool and Bristol in the same way UK Border Force officers man posts at the Channel Tunnel in Calais.Insiders said the move could help break the Irish border deadlock in Brexit talks and &ldquoshow willing to Brussels.9.56am update: Ireland seeks special customs deal with EUIreland is negotiating a special Brexit side deal allowing it to use Britain as a &ldquoland bridge for goods in transit to Dublin.A senior Irish tax official said the agreement would see goods from the continent undergo checks in Calais where they would be sealed and given free passage to Dublin via Dover and Holyhead.Carol-Ann O&rsquoKeeffe, an assistant principal of corporate affairs and customs ision at Revenue, said: &ldquoThere are negotiations going on at EU level where the regulatory check would have been done in France and we are hopeful that those goods will be sealed and can travel through the UK and come to Ireland then.9.28am update: Guy Verhofstadt launches Twitter tiradeGuy Verhofstadt has lash out at member states &ldquowho take EU money without embracing the bloc&rsquos values.In a thinly-veiled swipe at eurosceptic governments in Hungary and Poland the senior Belgian MEP said: &ldquoThere is no place in our union for countries who take EU money but reject our shared values!The blast follows France&rsquos Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian making it clear his country will not finance a populist Europe.8.30am update: Chambers of Commerce boss said Brexit could boost businessBritish Chambers of Commerce boss Adam Marshall has suggested Brexit could serve as a kick in the backside for UK businesses, pushing them to invest more of their time and resources into global markets.In a speech at the London Business School, Mr Marshall claimed disruption could be good in the short term as it could lead businesses to be on the ball of global trends.He said: This whole process is going to serve as a kick in the backside for many of our businesses in this country.There&rsquos a little bit of a sense that it hurts right now but disruption might actually be good for many businesses over the long-term because it may lead many of them to become better businesses.

title: house of fraser administration darlington sofa fiona boston
story: Sports Direct to be 'Selfridges of Sport'                 House of Fraser dodges administration as Mike Ashley seals &pound90m dealShe said: &ldquoOn July 26 I bought the sofa and chair. I&rsquod had my eye on it for a couple of years, it was a perfect fit for my home.&ldquoI paid in cash and three days later I went back to buy some extras on my debit card which cost &pound715.&ldquoMy husband Alan had an aneurism last year and it&rsquos taking him a while to get back to full health, but he&rsquod been sitting on deck chairs at home as we were still waiting. He deserved to be comfortable.&ldquoI kept asking the manager and staff but they were saying everything was out of their hands.Fiona Boston on her House of Fraser sofa claimed after the chain went into administration (Image: EVENING GAZETTE)Fiona Boston sent men in to House of Fraser to take the sofa (Image: EVENING GAZETTE)The delivery dates for Fiona&rsquos purchases were continually put back and she went back to the store on several occasions to ask when she would get them and to check the sofa was still in store.But then House of Fraser went into administration and Fiona lost her money, along with the sofa.She added: &ldquoThey told me I would be put on a list of creditors and to wait to get my money back. I knew that the chances were I wouldn&rsquot be getting it back.&ldquoThey even told me I could take finance out on the sofa - but I refused to pay for it twice.So with the sofa she&rsquod paid for sitting in the Darlington store, Fiona decided to take matters into her own hands on September 1.&ldquoI got some of my family together, some strong lads and a van from Scott Bros in Haverton Hill, and decided to go to the store late in the afternoon when it was quite empty.Fiona Boston on her claimed sofa from House of Fraser (Image: EVENING GAZETTE)Fiona wanted the sofa to make her husband Alan comfortable after an aneurism (Image: EVENING GAZETTE)&ldquoWe went up to the second floor, took the sofa apart and walked right out the front door. No one batted an eyelid.But as soon as the sofa was loaded onto the van, staff surrounded the vehicle.&ldquoThey told me that they&rsquod call the police as it was theft. I said I&rsquod paid for it and had a receipt.Fiona, who works as a market trader, drove off but was soon pulled over by the police where she explained what happened.&ldquoI showed him my receipt and that it was rightfully mine.&ldquoHe wasn&rsquot happy but called his inspector who said it was a civil matter and to let us drive off.Fiona Boston after she and her friends successfully took the sofa from House of Fraser (Image: EVENING GAZETTE)&ldquoSo we did. It&rsquos what you call British justice.Fiona says she is still owed &pound716 by House of Fraser but her husband Alan, 66, can now relax comfortably on the sofa they&rsquod waited so long for.Express has contacted House of Fraser for comment.House of Fraser&rsquos stores in Middlesbrough and Darlington were both under threat when the firm went into administration.However their new owner, Sports Direct&rsquos billionaire founder Mike Ashley, said he would try to keep 80 percent of the chain&rsquos stores open after he bought the company out of administration.It was announced last week that both stores would remain open.

story: Gerard Lyons criticised the euro and warned against the path the European Union is currently heading in.Speaking exclusively to Express, Mr Lyons, co-author of Clean Brexit and Chief Economic Strategist at Netwealth Investments, explained the major problems with the euro.He said: &ldquoI think one of the biggest challenges with the European Union is that at its core it&rsquos a fundamentally flawed economic system, namely the euro.&ldquoThe euro was driven by politics, not by economics. And the euro has been at the root cause of all the problems we have see in the European Union in recent years and indeed in recent decades. I still think that is the biggest challenge.                Pound to euro exchange rate picks up despite low high street sales                Pound euro exchange rate: GBP muted as Hammond warns of no-deal Brexit&ldquoIndeed, if one looks at the EU at the&nbspmoment&nbspor the euro system in particular. There is something called TARGET2, very technical it sounds, but it reflects underlying economic imbalances within the euro area.&ldquoI think that is the big challenge. More than Europe led by&nbspGermany&nbspis worried by the fact that they will have to make continued fiscal transfers.&ldquoSouthern Europe, reflected in&nbspthe recent&nbspelection in Italy, is worried that they will have to bow to, and have their hands tied behind their backs on economic policy.&ldquoSo, I think there are deep routed tensions within the euro system. And it has been widely accepted, since its inception, is the way the euro can survive is to move closer and closer to a political union.Mr&nbspLyons added: &ldquoNow I think the key thing for us in the UK to understand in the last&nbspyear-and-a-half&nbspsince we voted to leave.President Macron and others within the EU have talked about these challenges and they have pointed out that either the EU, led by the euro area itself, needs to move towards a closer political union.&ldquoOr it needs to move to&nbspsystem, where there are countries on the periphery.&ldquoWe need to ask ourselves do we want to be part of a system where will be pulled into a political union. And the referendum result would say no.&ldquoOr do we want to be part of a system where we would be on the periphery, where we would have little control and say, and clearly most people in the UK would say no.Gerard Lyons claimed the euro was 'fundamentally flawed' (Image: EXPRESS&bull)&ldquoI think we need to accept that we are leaving. Have a sensible relationship with the EU, but at the same time make sure that future relationship does not tie our hands with domestic economic policy, or our ability to do trade deals with countries across the world.The Brexit supporting economist also criticised the Prime Minister&rsquos Chequers plan warning it could &ldquotie Britain&rsquos hands when trying to secure trade deals with countries around the world post-Brexit.Prime Minister Theresa May has vowed to stick to her controversial blueprint despite criticism from pro-Brexit MPs within her own party.Former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson increased pressure on the Prime Minister this week with a damning article against her Chequers plan.

title: british monarchy the queen news lords heredity members
story: He echoed the words of the late Lord Napier and Ettrick, who claimed the survival of the monarchy in the 21st century could also be at stake as a result of 1999 reforms to remove the majority of hereditary peers from the Lords.Lord Shinkwin's remarks emerged as Labour peer Lord Grocott's House of Lords (Hereditary Peers) (Abolition of By-elections) Bill returned for debate.There are up to 92 hereditary peers remaining, with calls for change intensifying after a 2016 Liberal Democrat hereditary peer by-election cost taxpayers &pound300 and involved just three voters.The Government said it would not block the Bill but believes it has no prospect of clearing all the necessary stages in the current parliamentary session to become law.                House of Lords calls EMERGENCY Brexit meeting during summer recess                Remainer compares no-deal Brexit to holding gun to his own headAmid claims of filibustering as amendments were pushed despite lacking support, the Bill failed to progress beyond committee stage as time ran out on Friday.Lord Shinkwin, speaking ahead of the committee stage resuming on the Bill, said: Some may say that the hereditary principle is out of date, but surely it is the politics of envy which is outdated - not the noble principle of public service handed down through the generations.A duty to serve in the Lords should never be regarded as an anachronism.Were this Bill to be passed, there would be no going back. That would be it. We would not be ending a chapter of our history, so much as turning our back on it.The future of the British monarchy could be at risk (Image: )Lord Shinkwin added: I feel we should press the pause button because I'm not sure we fully appreciate what we're deleting.We would be deleting a part of ourselves, a part of the fabric of the nation of immense worth.We should recognise that once lost, it'll not only be lost forever, it could be used by some as a precedent for which to attack other aspects of our great heritage.In conclusion, I simply remind the House that it was the late Lord Napier and Ettrick - whose heir I believe would be an asset to the House - who said in his valedictory speech on March 30 1999, 'what could be at stake here is the survival of the monarchy'.So I simply ask we be careful what we wish for, for in attacking the rich legacy of public service, that fundamental duty to serve - which we as a country and a kingdom have inherited - we impoverish ourselves.                Tory MP lists four steps for a &lsquoBETTER Brexit&rsquo to stop &lsquohumiliation'                EU is FAILING to stop money laundering - regulators issue warningBut Labour's Lord Desai, a supporter of the Bill, said: If we had not continually revolutionised the institutions by due process, we would not be where we are - we would have been long ago destroyed, like the French monarchy was destroyed.Tory Lord Cormack described himself as a fervent monarchist as he backed the Bill.Opinion on the proposed legislation was again split among peers, with Conservative Lord Trefgarne arguing the Government should bring forward measures to reform the Lords rather than backbench peers.But he faced claims of filibustering after moving a motion which delayed debate on amendments to the Bill.For Labour, Baroness Hayter of Kentish Town said: If we cannot even do this minor, minor thing... it doesn't seem to me we're actually very interested in bringing this House into the current century.Lord Young of Cookham, speaking for the Government, said there was no consensus on the measure and the Government had reservations, but added: Despite that, we have no plans to block the Bill or impede its progress.He added there were 13 speeches in favour of the Bill and eight against at second reading, noting it has no prospect of getting through the Commons.Labour's Lord Snape took aim at those who opposed the Bill, saying: Every time we debate this, like woolly mammoths, Lords Trefgarne and Caithness appear with a whole series of amendments.Crossbencher Lord Berkeley of Knighton said the debate had left him deeply ashamed and demanded the Government seize the nettle and back the Bill.It's disgraceful. We're trying to advantage a small section of society over another, he told the House.Conservative Lord True responded to say he would not be silenced by people saying I'm a disgrace or I bring disrepute on the House.

story: This week, the Labour&nbspMP Stephen Kinnock told Brexit minister Dominic Raab that the EU&rsquos chief negotiator Michel Barnier had said that Ms May&rsquos proposals were &ldquodead in the water.When pushed on more information, he said he had been told &ldquoles propositions sont mortes, which translates as &ldquothe proposals are dead.The EU has dismissed the allegation that Mr Barnier had made such comments during Monday&rsquos crunch talks with the Brexit select committee, which were held to discuss the progress of negotiations.Speaking to the BBC&rsquos new flagship politics show, Politics Live, Conservative MP Stephen Crabb corroborated the EU&rsquos denial, claiming that Mr Barnier had said no such thing and that he &ldquocertainly didn&rsquot use the phrase Stephen Kinnock referred to. Brussels RUBBISHES Labour&rsquos &lsquodead in water&rsquo claimMr Crabb said: &ldquoHe didn&rsquot say anything like that.&ldquoWhat he did say, was that when it comes to the Government&rsquos future trading relationship, which was set out in the Government&rsquos White Paper over the summer involving this slightly complicated customs arrangement and this so called &lsquocommon rule-book&rsquo, Michel Barnier was pretty clear about the strength of the EU Commission&rsquos concerns about those proposals.&ldquoI think it will require a leap of faith and optimism to think that the final future partnership between the UK and the EU will include exactly those propositions.&ldquoBut overall the Chequer&rsquos plan, which includes a lot more than just trade, is still very much alive, it still is the basis of ongoing talks.Brexit News: MP Stephen Crabb has denied that Mr Barnier had called the Chequer's proposals dead.  (Image: BBC )&ldquoMy money is still on a deal being struck by the end of the year.Journalist Chris Mason pressed him further on the issue, asking: &ldquoDying but not dead?Mr Crabb replied: &ldquoNot dead.Mrs May Chequer&rsquos plans have come under repeated attacks from across the political spectrum. story: Addressing Leader of the House Andrea Leadsom during Business Questions yesterday, Mr Wishart strengthened the SNP&rsquos calls for a second Scottish&nbspindependence referendum in the event that the UK exits the EU.Mr Wishart said: &ldquoIf Brexit goes ahead, the majority of people in Scotland now want independence for our nation as we refuse to go down with this stricken UK Brexit liner.&ldquoI bet the Leader of the House now wishes she&rsquod listen to the Scottish government when it comes to Brexit now.Ms Leadsom did not respond to his calls for a second Scottish referendum and instead referred to his first enquiry into a private members bill. title: lady not for learning theresa may
story: Will the headmistress have the authority to impose discipline on her unruly students?Two months ago, the Prime Minister shattered what was left of Conservative Party unity when she produced her plan for Brexit at Chequers.Having said Britain will take back control of our laws, money and borders, and strike our own trade deals around the world, she erased her red lines.At Chequers, she said Britain would follow certain EU laws, accept rulings of the European Court of Justice and adopt a customs policy that casts doubt on our ability to agree trade deals with other countries.Her Brexit Secretary, David Davis, and her Foreign Secretary, Boris Johnson, resigned in protest, and since then Westminster has waited anxiously to see what happens next.In the coming weeks and months, we will find out.Theresa May insists the choice is ­simple. She says we can leave in a safe and orderly manner through the Chequers plan or we can leave dangerously and chaotically if we don’t agree a departure deal with Europe.In truth, there are other choices. We could surrender less sovereignty by proposing a conventional trade agreement, as Davis suggested in a white paper that was rejected by the PM.But his proposal was never published, and Davis is now on the backbenches.We could join the European Economic Area, like Norway, leaving us subject to European laws, including free movement, and paying into the Brussels budget.Advocates, including the Tory MP Nick Boles, say this would buy us time to sort out our long-term relationship with Europe, but we would risk getting stuck half-in, half-out of the EU for years.Whatever the merits of his case, however, Boles is a backbench MP who cannot impose policy on the Government.Because Theresa May is the Prime Minister, Chequers is the only policy on the table. But Chequers, as bad as it already is, will not be the final deal.Downing Street insiders insist it is “obtainable” without further compromises, while the PM says she will not accept compromises “that are not in our national interest”. But this is the problem: There will be further compromises, which come on top of an already flawed proposal.And this is hardly a surprise, because Chequers is unacceptable to the Europeans.The EU’s number one rule is that the “four freedoms” of its single market — in goods, services, people and capital — cannot be divided.And yet Chequers — as unacceptable as it is to British Eurosceptics — seeks to divide these four freedoms.Britain is effectively asking to stay in the single market for trade in goods but not in services, people and capital.If we want what we have proposed for goods, the Europeans will say we must accept the other obligations.As part of an agreement about services, they will insist on Britain accepting more EU laws and a greater role for the European Court.They are likely to demand financial contributions and access to British waters for their fishing industry.And while they might not call it free movement, they will insist on concessions that grant Europeans almost automatic access to the British labour market.This prediction is not plucked out of thin air. It is based on decades of EU policymaking, and everything European leaders and their negotiators have said since the referendum.It is reflected in the EU’s own negotiating guidelines, issued to the European Commission by the Council of Ministers.And it is why, in her Lancaster House speech last year, Theresa May ruled out single market membership.Having to accept its obligations, she said, “would to all intents and purposes mean not leaving the EU at all”.And yet this is the danger we now face. According to several Government sources, the Chancellor, Philip Hammond, is “itching” to make a “generous offer” on immigration. Some believe he wants to retain free movement rules, because he says we cannot get a good trade deal unless we do so.Theresa May, on the other hand, is adamant that free movement must end.But whether or not we are legally part of EU free movement rules, the question is whether her deal will regain full control of immigration to Britain. And what we know already is alarming.There is nothing wrong with allowing tourists to come here easily, students to attend British universities and business people to travel without bureaucracy.Nor is there a problem with firms moving their workers across borders quickly and easily to provide services.And it makes sense to give Europeans preferential access to Britain compared to people from further away.But few ministers care about reducing immigration, and the Chequers white paper is remarkably open about the options. It proposes, for example, a “youth mobility scheme” that would give young Europeans the right to live and work in Britain for fixed periods.Without strict limits, this alone could destroy meaningful immigration control, because most people who want to migrate are young.Around 64 per cent of EU migrants to Britain are under 30, while 86 per cent are younger than 40.The white paper suggests “other specific mobility areas”, without giving further details. It proposes “social security coordination” which might allow migrants to claim benefits for children living back home in countries like Poland.And it says nothing about our ability to deport or bar European criminals from Britain.Most worryingly, there is no proposal for a visa system for European workers.Without that, unskilled and low-skilled immigration will continue without limit.It does not need to be like this.We are discussing these unacceptable compromises because Chequers proposes partial membership of the EU’s single market.If we want to escape Europe’s laws, its court and its demands for our money — and if we want to control immigration — the Government needs to revive its plans for a free trade agreement, and it needs to do so urgently.Unless it does, Brexit will not mean Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: isabel hardman mp dont deserve to represent
story: MPs trudged back to work in Westminster this week and yes, among their ­number were some who really don’t deserve the honour of representing us.It’s true that some politicians are the sort of stereotypical snouts-in-the-trough love rats that we all imagine when we think of a typical MP. But one of ­Parliament’s biggest secrets is that most of the men and women in it are actually pretty decent.What rightly makes voters angry with Parliament is that it doesn’t look like the country it represents, and approves policies that often make the world a worse place. In the current Parliament, 29 per cent of UK-educated MPs went to private schools.This is a record low, but it is out of step with the public, which is around seven per cent privately educated. Only 32 per cent of MPs are women, and 7.8 per cent are from ethnic minorities, while roughly 14 per cent of the general population is black or minority ethnic.The majority of MPs were already working in politics before being elected or held well-paid jobs as lawyers.In my new book, Why We Get The Wrong Politicians, I’ve discovered one of the main reasons why only well-off people become MPs. It’s because they have to spend tens of thousands of pounds of their own money on standing for Parliament.I asked 532 candidates who stood in the 2015 election how much it had cost them, and was shocked by the answers. The average cost for all candidates, whether they were standing in a seat that they’d certainly win, one where they might win or a no-hope constituency, was £11,118.For those who had to fight in marginal seats, the costs were even higher. Conservatives who won their seats spent £121,467. Their colleagues who failed to win still lost an average of £18,701.Labour was no better. If you won your seat, you lost around £19,022, but those who failed to get elected spent even more — £35,843.Some spent money they had saved to buy a home. Others maxed out their credit cards and are still paying off the debts today. This money didn’t go on leaflets or any of the other official campaign spending that is tightly regulated.Instead, it was working for free for up to two years, travelling around and sometimes even moving to the constituency, and attending local events. One broke candidate needed help from members of her party to pay her mortgage. She didn’t even win her seat.Another ex-candidate was delighted when he landed a new job and could afford to buy a house — before he realised he’d spent the deposit on campaigning, ironically for the “party of home ownership”.This ludicrous cost excludes so many people who would make much better MPs than the ones we currently have. MPs do not really do the job they’ve been elected to perform, anyway.The pressure is for them to do as their whips tell them, rather than to look at the legislation going through the House of Commons. Most vote on bills without realising what they might entail.Even when they are appointed to the bill committees scrutinising every line of a law, MPs in the governing party are told to sit quiet and vote with the Government every time. Many write their Christmas cards in these committees.From the “bedroom tax” to interventions in Iraq and Libya, MPs have failed to notice problems before they turn into real crises.It doesn’t have to be like this. The parties could pay their candidates to stand. The Conservatives have already announced a modest bursary fund, and Labour has toyed with the idea too. Other groups should stump up some funding as well.The Women’s Equality Party, for instance, is stunningly well-funded but has little chance of getting an MP elected. It would be much better to use that money to get more women MPs in all the political parties. Currently MPs don’t have to take any responsibility for approving dud policies.My book suggests a new stage for legislation, called “Public Payback Panels” where people directly affected by a government policy could ask the minister and members of the bill committee who approved it to explain why they voted the way they did.This would encourage politicians to take their job seriously and really look at the laws they were approving.If this doesn’t change, MPs will still have the most expensive job interview on Earth — and will then be told when they arrive in Parliament not to do their job. No wonder voters are angry.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: mick hume facebook lucy mchugh
story: Coming from the privacy- flogging, free speech-trampling bosses at Facebook, this “principled” stand over a child murder looks like a shameless display of hypocritical grandstanding. The company should be renamed Two-Facedbook.Lucy McHugh’s body was found in Hampshire woodland six weeks ago. She had been stabbed to death.Police arrested Stephen Nicholson, 24, a care worker who had been living with Lucy’s family, on suspicion of murder and sexual activity with a child.Nicholson admits being in contact with Lucy via Facebook on the evening before her disappearance and on the morning of the tragic day. But he refused to give police his Facebook password so they could check what was said.Nicholson was prosecuted for refusing to cooperate with the investigation. His lawyer said his client was afraid cops would find evidence of his involvement with cannabis.The judge dismissed this excuse as “wholly inadequate”, surely putting it mildly.Last week Nicholson was jailed for 14 months for preventing police from checking his messages. In the UK, failing to cooperate with police is an offence under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act. He got a much longer term than he would ever get for smoking dope.Meanwhile Facebook — a US company not bound by our laws — refused a police request to divulge Nicholson’s password.Detectives had to apply to the US authorities for an order giving access to Nicholson’s account. That process could take many months.Facebook insists it cannot give police quick access, because of its commitment to privacy and freedom of expression. That excuse sounds even more pathetic than Nicholson’s dopey cannabis story.Yes, privacy and free speech are crucial principles to defend, including online.But in practice, Facebook has as much regard for those freedoms as a police-state apparatchik.Its bosses’ one serious commitment is to their freedom to rake in cash. They monitor our private lives and make money off our likes and desires.Facebook and other tech giants use our online activity to target advertising and allow companies access to our data. As for free speech, Facebook has been busy closing right-wing pages that do not suit its leftie Silicon Valley tastes.It says it will not tolerate “hate speech and harassment”. When it comes to child murder suspects, it apparently takes a more liberal attitude.Facebook has bizarrely chosen the case of Stephen Nicholson to strike a phoney pose as a stalwart defender of privacy and freedom.Double standards don’t come much lower. This looks like a grossly misjudged attempt at moral grandstanding designed to repair Facebook’s right-on reputation.It appears more likely to have the opposite effect, lowering its standing still further.We should never take the issue of privacy and state intervention lightly. In a free society, the police should not be given licence to pry and poke into our affairs and online activities as they see fit.We must be on our guard against the creeping advance of state snooping.But the demand for privacy can also be used to the detriment of a free and civilised society. After Sir Cliff Richard won his privacy case against the BBC over the reporting of a police raid on his home, many have demanded “Cliff’s law” be enforced to prevent the media naming those suspected of serious crimes.In a terrible case such as the murder of Lucy McHugh, it surely ought to be possible to work out a fast way to access the chief suspect’s Facebook account — he having chatted with the victim shortly before she disappeared — without declaring open season for police snoopers.The law must be changed to help police get data in cases like this — so long as that law is tightly framed and properly scrutinised.Facebook can posture and hide behind the US courts but our media is subject to a full book of laws that have empowered police and state agencies to demand news- papers hand over sensitive information and name their confidential sources. No passwords required. Some publishers, it seems, have more freedom than others.Facebook’s two-faced bosses should be brought to book for their double standards on privacy and their blatant disregard for the public good. As the site asks, let them know what we’re thinking.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. But I didn’t really know what I was doing.”As I’ve said before, Corbyn’s defence is always to portray himself as a complete moron who doesn’t know where he is or what he’s doing. It doesn’t wash. He’s an anti-Semite.But there’s another group of people who know this only too well. And they’re doing very little about it.That’s the Labour MPs. The ones who cannot abide Corbyn and Momentum and want him gone. The Old Labour Party, the one we used to have before the lefty infants took over.But they do nothing. Not a thing, apart from moan quietly in the background.If ever there was a time for a split, for a new party to be formed which might capture the attention of the voters, this is it.But they don’t have the balls. Or they are scared to lose their safe seats and their nice incomes. That’s probably a false hope too, mind. Corbyn isn’t going anyplace anytime soon.And if he did another lunatic would take over who might conceivably be worse. And Momentum now control the entire party. So, one after another, the moderate Labour MPs will be deselected and lose their seats anyway.The ones who think Israel has a right to exist.The ones who don’t think Cuba and Venezuela have particularly brilliant governments.The ones who don’t want to police newspapers which don’t agree with them.The MPs whose first consideration is poverty and inequality, not identity politics and fatuous agitprop grandstanding.So far only one of these has made a stand — the excellent Frank Field. He has resigned the Labour whip, disgusted at ­Corbyn’s anti-Semitism.All it would take is three or four more and suddenly we would have a new political party.So, what about it, Kate Hoey? And the former Blairite, Caroline Flint? And Ben Bradshaw? And John Mann?Are you telling me you’re happy where you are, in today’s Labour Party? Or are you just waiting for someone to come and rescue you?You’ve got a long wait. You have to do it yourselves.I WAS feeling a bit sorry for Roxanne Pallett.She made a mistake, only a kid really – and now she’s lost everything.And then I saw an interview with her.Dense as a slab of tungsten – although I suppose that’s not her fault.I mean, if you were born with only a five-watt bulb flickering away inside your skull it’s not something that can be changed very easily, is it?But more than that, it was her absolute self-absorption.Everything was about me, me, me.Not the hurt she had caused to others, but the misery she’d inflicted on HERSELF.It’s a common condition these days, I suppose.But Pallett is a pretty extreme example.SEEN what’s been happening in Germany?Huge demonstrations against immigration in Chemnitz, formerly Karl-Marx Stadt.The BBC and others say it’s all the “far right”. Neo Nazis. People with posters of Hitler in their bedrooms.I daresay there are a few nasty types on those marches who wish there was still a Gestapo. But I think the vast majority of those demonstrating are ordinary German citizens, sick of what has happened to their country.And the same thing has been happening across Europe.It’s not the far right at all, no matter how often the liberals tell you it is.GREAT call from the President of the Philippines, a bloke called Rodrigo Duterte.According to him, if women want to avoid being raped they should not be so beautiful.Maybe they should have all their teeth removed? Men won’t want to give one to someone who is totally toothless. It’ll put them off completely.The women could also slice their noses off.Or have facial surgery to make them resemble an anteater or a pipistrelle bat.The world has its fair share of dimbo leaders. But Rodrigo is right there near the top.SO the latest plan is to put road markings on the pavement.It’s so zombies attached to their iPhones, staring at the ground, don’t walk into the middle of a road or off the edge of a cliff.There has been a rise in accidents involving pedestrians who are locked tightly into their own little world.I have been nearly flattened by joggers immersed in some crap pounding through their thick skulls. And nobody talks to anybody any more. We discuss banning the burka from public spaces.But is there anything more antisocial than someone with their head down, oblivious to the world around them?ANNOYED that her partner had allegedly cheated on her, Serena Reynoldson filmed herself pouring bleach into his tropical fish tank while cackling, “Die, die, die!” Which is what they did, of course.I think her ex, Jon Fitzpatrick, is well out of it, frankly.It all seems a bit hard on the poor fish. So far as we know, they hadn’t cheated on Ms Reynoldson. Mr Fitzpatrick also had a snake, which was lucky to get out of the place alive.I think the moral is if you’re going to upset your missus, make sure you have pets that can look after themselves. A Tasmanian devil, say, or a king cobra.WHY has Jose Mourinho not been sacked by Manchester United?I don’t mean because his team are not terribly good. Or about as pleasing to watch as John Prescott eating a curry.But he’s just been handed a one-year suspended prison sentence and hit with whopping fines – for tax evasion running into the millions of pounds.Does Manchester United not have any principles?I’LL be glued to the box watching The Mighty Redcar on BBC2 tonight. Seeing that the town is only a stone’s throw from my gaff in Saltburn.I was worried at first that it was just another poverty-porn film.You know, when the BBC turns up somewhere north of Watford so everyone can have a good old snigger at the people who live there.But having spoken to some of the people who took part, it isn’t like that at all.Redcar’s had it rough and wages are low. Both Labour and the Tories have let down the steelworkers, who are no more.But there are plenty of new businesses thriving, beyond the BBC’s cameras.Redcar will be just fine in the end, just as it was when I lived there in the Seventies.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: now we know for sure putin sent assassins to britain we must target russia
story: The man President Macron shamefully cosied up to at the World Cup final is a psychopathic tyrant who dispatches sneaky killers wielding weapons of war.And how did this gangster state react yesterday to being exposed? By sniggering at Theresa May’s dancing.Russia must face tougher sanctions. The international community must demand the suspects be handed over for trial.Britain must hit back at Putin’s spy network and his oligarch mates who launder their dirty money in London.The Sun congratulates our intelligence services and police on their diligence and skill in identifying these hitmen. Some 11,000 hours of CCTV was sifted.But where does this all leave Comrade Cob? Six months ago Corbyn, briefed by his Trotskyite lackey Seumas Milne, parroted Putin’s line. Even yesterday, with hard evidence before him, he still couldn’t condemn the Russian regime.Imagine — with one murdered and three stricken by Novichok — if the Kremlin’s useful idiot had been our Prime Minister.OUR leftie Archbishop of Canterbury has a revolutionary idea: tax the rich! But his ­solutions are standard lazy Labour fare, ignoring inconvenient facts:Inequality has been falling for years. The richest one per cent pay 27 per cent of all income tax, as opposed to just 11 under Labour in the 1970s. Raising the top rate nets LESS money since the wealthiest find ways to avoid it, or leave.Low corporation tax is partly behind the incredible job creation since 2010. Reverse it and see the dole queues grow.And an avalanche of taxes on wealth won’t bring equality. The overall burden is near a 30-year high. Raising it further will kill aspiration, investment and jobs.To help the poor, CUT their taxes instead.WE’RE not swallowing the Treasury scares about jobs being at risk if restaurants are made to put calorie counts on their menu.Food apps can assess a dish’s calories in moments. Totting up a menu is a few hours’ work once in a while.Better that than impose more nanny-state taxes to crowbar diners off grub they like. It’s far more likely to persuade them to pick a healthier option too.The problem is enforcing it. We don’t want council “calorie cops” giving firms a hard time. title: monster martin selmayr proves eu gangsters
story: We silly old Brits misunderstand the legal foundations of the grand European project.When our Brexit negotiators ask it to compromise — on trade, the Northern Ireland border or migration — we forget that the European Union and the 27 other member states simply cannot bend or break its inviolable rules.This turns out to be hokum, as will be apparent to anyone who has read a report into Brussels chicanery published this week by the European ombudsman.The EU elite, it is clear, break the rules whenever it suits them and with impunity.Emily O’Reilly’s report focuses on the unstoppable rise of Martin Selmayr, the German right-hand man of European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker.Selmayr is known as the “monster of the Berlaymont” after the EU headquarters in Brussels where his word is law.Earlier this year he was appointed, in shady circumstances, secretary-general of the commission, which he now effectively runs. The stitch-up reeked.When MEPs found out, even the European parliament was appalled.The improper manoeuvre will keep Selmayr, a devout federalist, at the centre of power for years to come and long after his patron Jean-Claude Juncker has retired to spend more time with his wine cellar.How did they pull it off?The outgoing secretary-general had told Juncker, privately, he would retire this year.Armed with Juncker’s inside knowledge, Selmayr successfully applied to be deputy.Then, at a meeting of commissioners, Juncker revealed the secretary-general post was suddenly vacant and that, as luck would have it, Selmayr was ready to fill it.The ombudsman’s conclusions on what the pair did are scathing. Four serious breaches of protocol and maladministration are listed.Selmayr did not take appropriate measures to avoid conflict of interest. The rules of procedure were broken.“A situation of urgency to fill the post of secretary-general was created artificially,” O’Reilly says, and: “The commissioners  responsible for the maladministration in this case. It is extraordinary that no commissioner seemed to question the secretary-general appointment procedure, which in the end raised valid widespread concerns.”Extraordinary is putting it mildly.The report makes for shocking, if not surprising, reading. The rules-based Brussels order and its highly paid apparat behave like a gangster racket.Just to be helpful, I’m going to send a copy of O’Reilly’s report to every EU flag-waving “People’s Vote” campaigner and to Gary Lineker, the crisp- toting TV football host, who has emerged as a leading voice in the campaign for a second referendum.Needless to say, Selmayr and Juncker face no sanctions or punishment.Instead, O’Reilly recommends that the commission should develop a new procedure — I’m sure that will help — for appointing the next secretary-general.My first thought on reading her report was that the commission is an even more appalling and arrogant organisation than it looks, sitting at the heart of an imperious EU wedded to ever-closer integration.Thank goodness we’re leaving. But are we?To listen to the hysterical wailing of the People’s Vote crowd in recent weeks, you would think that Brexit is about to be stopped and a grateful public will beg to be bossed around by Selmayr and his goons for years to come.There isn’t the parliamentary time for another referendum before we leave on March 29 and it’s an exceptionally duff idea regardless.If there can be two referendums, why leave it at that? Why not make it best of three or five? The decision to leave has been taken. Britain is quitting the EU.Thank goodness, in my view a shame, in the view of others — what matters now are the terms.Here, the Tory party is engaged in a row with itself over the Prime Minister’s Chequers proposal, which envisages Britain sticking with the EU’s rule book on goods.It is astonishing to see how purist this has made some of my fellow-Brexiteers who spent years before the referendum acknowledging in private that there would have to be compromises.Not long ago, Boris Johnson was so torn by the nuanced arguments on either side that he plumped for Leave by the narrowest of margins. Now he plays the zealot.But contrary to the prophets of doom, the Chequers proposal isn’t dead yet.No10 is adamant that it has “unlocked the talks” and that, beneath the rhetoric of the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier, progress is being made that may become apparent at the Salzburg meeting of EU leaders on September 20.In a weird way it might work. With Theresa May’s internal critics split and producing almost as many alternative Brexit plans as there are Tory MPs, Labour divided, and other EU member states anxious that we don’t leave without a deal, something like the Chequers plan remains the best one on offer.It would satisfy non-obsessives like me to just agree a deal, improve it as we go along, and get on with life beyond Brexit. Life is full of compromises.This is sacrilege to my purist friends. But soon, hardline Conservative MPs must decide whether they care so much about ideology that they are prepared to vote down an imperfect deal.If they do that, they risk losing the lot.And by opening the way to emergency extensions of our membership until we come up with another plan, they could condemn Britain to staying in the awful organisation that elevated Martin Selmayr to power.Times/News SyndicationOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says energy price cap
story: We don’t like urging Government interference in what should be free markets. But where they are rigged and broken, where greedy monopolies ­routinely rip off the public for essential services, we will make exceptions.And if the Business Secretary follows through his threat to go after other profiteers whose business model relies on exploitation, we’ll back him.What choice was there with the Big Six? They were repeatedly warned to stop their unjustified price hikes — and laughed in the Government’s face.Yes, customers should switch supplier. But it’s not easy and many don’t, or can’t. They should not be treated as cashpoint machines by unscrupulous corporations.The failing water and rail firms should be next. But the nationalisations Labour lazily clamour for are a recipe for shoddy service, strikes and crippling losses to taxpayers, as in the past. The answer is MORE privatisation, more competition.Because these aren’t truly free ­markets. Until they are, firms enjoying effective monopolies should expect far greater Government scrutiny and action than those who genuinely compete.“We’re in a different age now,” Mr Clark says. Good.CORBYN’S Labour hope to sneak into power on a pack of lies.It’s not just that their economics are a fantasy that would plunge us into ­poverty. Look at their other positions:Corbyn and his No2 John McDonnell both now admit they would never use our nukes, even under attack. A Corbyn Britain would thus abandon our deterrent, whatever Labour’s manifesto says.Will they ever be honest enough to tell voters they would unilaterally disarm, just as the world gets more dangerous?Honesty, though, is not their strong suit.Yesterday McDonnell repeated the absurd lie that he only wanted “peace” in Northern Ireland. He and Corbyn wanted IRA victory, achieved through ­murder. McDonnell wanted Provos “honoured”. He praised them for bombing their way to the negotiating table.As for the anti-Semite Corbyn, how chuffed he must be that 40 per cent of Jews could flee Britain if he wins power. How proud that Corbynite racists plaster Jew-hating posters across London.It’s what happens when you campaign, as Corbyn did, for the right to be more racist towards Jews than the international anti-Semitism definitions allow.And then there’s Brexit, and the insanely dangerous second referendum he seems increasingly ready to back.But at least Leavers would then know who betrayed them.
