title: brexit news eus chief negotiator
story: NewsBrexit news: EU’s chief negotiator REJECTS Theresa May’s plan for leaving EuropeMichel Barnier said two points in the Prime Minister’s Chequers proposal were “not acceptable”Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor20:56, 7 SEP 2018NewsMichel Barnier also rejected a suggestion by Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg that the “divorce bill” of around £40billion agreed by Mrs May represents a payment for a future trade deal and could be withheld. "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe EU’s chief negotiator today rejected Theresa May’s plan for Brexit. Michel Barnier said two points in the Prime Minister’s Chequers proposal were “not acceptable”. He also said the future of the Irish border remained the “main obstacle” to a withdrawal agreement. The comments made to MPs on Monday emerged yesterday in a translation of the meeting. Asked by MP Hilary Benn whether the Chequers plan was “dead in the water”, Mr Barnier replied: “In the White Paper there are lots of positive things, lots of useful things. I did not just reject the White Paper outright.” He said Brussels will not accept Mrs May’s proposals on customs or her suggestion the UK and EU could have a free trade area which excluded services. He said: “The proposals are not acceptable on customs and on the common rulebook for goods.”  On Mrs May’s suggestion that the UK could carry out customs checks for the EU, he said: “Your proposal does not seem workable to us.” He told MPs he was “very concerned about Ireland” and that the suggestion put forward by some Brexiteers that the border could simply be kept open, was “too easy” because neither the EU or the UK could protect their consumers and businesses. But he said that the EU was “open” to discussing other arrangements for Northern Ireland than the Brussels proposal for it to remain within the European customs area, which has been rejected by Mrs May. Mr Barnier also rejected a suggestion by Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg that the “divorce bill” of around &pound40billion agreed by Mrs May represents a payment for a future trade deal and could be withheld.

title: one russias top ex kgb
story: NewsTop ex-KGB officer says Vladimir Putin may order more UK assassinations unless Government hits backEXCLUSIVE: In an extraordinary interview, Oleg Kalugin tonight told the Mirror the president saw Britain as a “soft touch”Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPaul MartinAndy Lines21:37, 7 SEP 2018Updated21:41, 7 SEP 2018NewsFormer KGB officer Oleg Kalugin says Theresa May should now kick out the Russian ambassador after the novichok poisonings"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Russia’s top ex-KGB officers says Vladimir Putin could order more assassinations here unless the Government hits back. In an extraordinary interview, Oleg Kalugin tonight told the Mirror the president saw Britain as a “soft touch”. The former general said Theresa May should now kick out the Russian ambassador after the novichok poisonings. And he warned of the possibility of further Salisbury-style attacks. Speaking after Britain named the alleged assassins as Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov, Mr Kalugin said: “The Russians see Britain as a soft touch. “I would not rule out more assassinations. “Now that you’ve identified two assassins, I feel Britain should at the very least expel the Russian ambassador. That would send a proper signal.”  He added: “Putin is not afraid to attack those of his enemies who he thinks betrayed him personally. He would have no scruples about doing so again, through whatever agency.” Mr Kalugin, formerly chief of KGB counter-intelligence, is still on the run. If he returns to Russia he will spend the rest of his life in jail. And Mr Kalugin believes he would have been killed long ago if he lived in the UK. He was Putin’s boss when they both worked in the KGB in Leningrad in the 1970s. The pair now hate each other. Mr Kalugin was so senior, he was one of only three men in a meeting in which the KGB sanctioned the assassination of Bulgarian dissident Georgi Markov, via a poisoned umbrella, in London in 1978. And he told of his surprise over claims Russia used its GRU military intelligence unit to carry out the Salisbury attack. He said: “The only thing that has surprised me about the Skripal attack was that, according to the British, the attackers were from the GRU.  “In my days, the GRU was only there to pick up military secrets. Dealing with traitors was only a job for us, the KGB.” He added of the nature of the attack: “Just note how differently the Russians, and before them the Soviets, have acted in the US. Yes, they interfere in elections but they have never, to my certain knowledge, even attempted a political assassination on US soil. “Of course, Britain has less means to make Putin feel threatened. But it’s been lacking in strong counter-action.” Mr Kalugin went on: “Internally, I’m not sure Britain realises the dangers. Intelligence activities have been re-activated by Putin after something of a lull under [his predecessor] Boris Yeltsin. “So far, the British Government and security agencies have failed in their job. Sergei Skripal served them well as a double agent, so how could they leave him unprotected in Salisbury? “Skripal was a full colonel in Russia’s military intelligence. He was an obvious target for Russian revenge.”  Mr Kalugin lives with his Russian wife in a small bungalow on the east coast of the US, where he once posed as a reporter during his spy days. Speaking of a future visit to the UK, he said: “I know this could expose me to Putin’s assassins, but I don’t care. I’ve had a full life and I’m an old man. “My last trip to Britain was very unpleasant. The police picked me up as I arrived at Heathrow. They interrogated me about Markov. “But our embassy got me out the next day and I flew back to Moscow. I was not the killer of Georgi Markov.” But he said: “I was one of only three men who discussed whe&shyther the KGB should help the Bulgarians in &shyMarkov’s killing. I sat at KGB headquarters in 1978 with our chief Yuri Andropov [later Soviet Union President] and his deputy. It was his decision. “My department, counter-intelligence, never carried out killings. Our job was to get secret information.” Mr Kalugin went on: “Our science and technology directorate had the weapon designed and constructed in Japan. It was an umbrella that fired a small dart into Markov’s leg. I believe that department still exists.”  He said British security services should have learned after failing to protect defector Alexander Litvinenko, poisoned in London in 2006. Mr Kalugin said: “He met with his killers more than once without MI5 intervening or getting close protect&shy&shyion. “It didn’t take a genius to work out Litvinenko’s life was deeply in danger.” Mr Kalugin was called an American stooge by Putin. He said: “I publicly accused Putin of being a mass murderer for waging war in Chechnya. “I’ve also had the guts to attack Putin in a book. If I had been living in Britain instead of the US, I would have been dead long ago.” And he warned it was possible British intelligence services still have Russian double agents within them. Mr Kalugin said: “We had between 10 and 20 agents inside MI5 and MI6 when I was in charge of foreign counter-intelligence. Russia’s intelligence services, who took over from the KGB, still have that capability.” He added of Salisbury: “I think more will emerge in the next few weeks.” War game is a serious show of strength to UK  By Chris Hughes   DEFENCE AND SECURITY EDITOR  Russian President Vladimir Putin is staging war games involving 300,000 troops – and a social media campaign to wreck enemy morale. Led by military intelligence wing GRU and Spetsnaz special forces, the exercise will roll through Siberia for four days from September 11 to 15 and will include Chinese and Mongolian troops.

title: tuc 150th anniversary boss frances
story: NewsTUC 150th anniversary: Boss Frances O'Grady speaks about zero hour contracts, low pay and the rise of the Just About ManagingO’Grady's job – battling hard Tory Brexit, the eighth year of turbo-austerity, and the spectre of automation – is among the toughest public roles in the country but she is rarely short of inspirationShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist20:47, 7 SEP 2018Updated20:49, 7 SEP 2018NewsTUC general secretary Frances O'Grady has spoken to The Mirror about the issues confronting workers "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFrances O’Grady is listening to a group of underpaid care workers in a supermarket cafe. “I love my job,” one &shyexhausted woman is telling the TUC’s General Secretary. “But I’ve only had a &pound3 rise in 21 years. How much more do things cost now? “I do hours overtime, anyway. I can’t rush visits because these are elderly people, and I don’t get paid travel time. I do 50 visits some days. It’s slave labour, really, but we do it because we care.” O’Grady, 58, is in Manchester for a speech at the Mechanics Institute – the birthplace of the Trades Union Congress – as part of &shycelebrations ahead of its 150th Congress, which starts on Sunday. But these women are on the front line of modern-day labour – underpaid workers rinsed in the new zero-hour economy run by distant corporations. With the support of Unison, the care workers have recently won a court case over petrol money and are now fighting over 15-minute visits and travel time. The General Secretary has just come from the early morning picket line at Wigan Hospital, where NHS cleaners and porters are fighting privatisation.  Her job – battling hard Tory Brexit, the eighth year of turbo-austerity, and the spectre of automation – is among the toughest public roles in the country but she is rarely short of inspiration. “Those women on the picket line know we’ve got to stand up for each other,” O’Grady says. “That’s what trade unionism is.” The TUC was born in tough times, when working people were being crushed under the wheels of the Industrial Revolution. At the Mechanics Institute we sit in the room where a “congress of trades councils and other federations of trades societies” came together in 1868. A portrait of George Potter, a joiner and cabinet maker who became the first President of the TUC, hangs on the wall. O’Grady’s own heroes include Mary Macarthur, the 1903 General Secretary of the Women’s Trades Union League. “I love the way she was cutting edge,” O’Grady says, perhaps thinking of the TUC’s new app aimed at young people. “She was getting films into cinemas at the turn of the century, she brought the strikes to the people. There was also that little bit of civil disobedience, a bit of cheekiness. She wasn’t brow-beaten.”  O’Grady laughs. “And, Anne &shyScargill,” she says of the founder of Women Against Pit Closures and ex-wife of miners’ leader Arthur. “She’s still going for it at 80. No flashy ego and a twinkle in her eye. I remember when she occupied that mine. It’s ‘what are we going to do about it?’ Not the big I Am.” O’Grady’s day in Manchester is all “what are we going to do about it?” – not the Big I Am. She would rather not talk about herself, or the great founders of the movement. Instead, she meets the brilliant Rusholme bus drivers from Unite. They took strike action against First Manchester last winter after realising they were being paid nearly &pound5,000 a year less than colleagues at a depot just five miles away.  “We knew they weren’t just going to give it to us,” Unite’s Neil Clarke tells O’Grady. “We knew we were going to have to stand outside for it. But the support we had was amazing. We just wanted the same pay for the same conditions in the same city for the same job. And in the end, we won.” At St Peter’s Square, O’Grady meets the inspirational TGI Fridays strikers, some as young as 18. “We were suddenly told that 40% of service charge payments were now going to top up kitchen wages,” a waitress tells her. “We understand kitchen staff are underpaid, but why is their pay rise coming out of our pockets? This isn’t a struggling family business.” The 150th Congress, which O’Grady will address on Monday, takes place within hours of the 10th anniversary of the collapse of Lehman Brothers, which former staff are celebrating with a party. “I don’t have a problem with reunions,” says O’Grady, dryly. “But I feel sick nothing’s really changed. Those bankers got off scot-free.  “Yet there are one million more children in relative poverty since 2010. And for the majority of poor children, their mums and dads are in work. So the Tory idea that work is the best route out of poverty is one big fat lie. They work all the hours God sends and yet they are no better off. We have to do something about the greed at the top. It’s not about resenting someone’s success but about being made a fool of, taking people for mugs. “A lot of people heard Theresa May talking about the Just About Managings and thought maybe she would do something about it. Apparently not.” The youngest of five children in an Irish, working-class household, O’Grady grew up in family that was often just about managing. As we talk about a free uniform scheme in Manchester, she nods. “I remember we couldn’t afford the school skirt, which was box-pleated. I had to have one with pleats all around it. It was amazing how conscious I was of it.” She shakes her head. “We’ve got to get wages rising. We need a bloody big lift to the minimum wage.” O’Grady grew up the youngest daughter of James, a chrome fitter and shop steward at the British Leyland carworks in Cowley, Oxford, and Rita, a shopworker who later worked for the NHS.

title: devastated fish chip shop owner
story: NewsDevastated fish and chip shop owner dies of 'broken heart' just weeks after husband's deathSteven Collyer, from Torquay, died just six weeks after partner Jason Roe passed away following an illnessShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByColleen Smith23:07, 7 SEP 2018NewsSteven and Jason, pictured on their wedding day, died within weeks of each other "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devastated chip shop owner died of a broken heart just weeks after the death of his husband, according to friends. Steven Collyer died just six weeks after partner Jason Roe passed away following an illness.  Tributes have been paid to the couple, who lived in Torquay, Devon Live reports.  Steven, 52, had been with Jason for 28 years, and were well known in the Cardiff gay community, where he ran a number of venues before moving to the south coast. Flowers, online messages and flags have been raised in memory of Steven, who died on Tuesday, September 4.  The couple had become an important part of the community in Shiphay since opening the top-rated fish and chip shop. Before moving to Devon they also had a 'massive impact' on the gay community in Cardiff where Steven opened the first WOW gay venue in the 1990s. He also ran Koolers Nightclub and Club Cardiff. Steve and Jason had been together for 28 years and close friend Jade Smith said: Steven died of a broken heart six weeks after Jason. Jade, who was the keyholder for the Shiphay Chippy said: Steven will be sadly missed by each and every one he met.

title: drink driver loses dream job
story: NewsDrink-driver loses 'dream job' after crashing into parked car on night outMegan Fairfield, from Lancashire, ploughed her red Audi into the car when she was more than twice the legal drink driving limitShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJon MacphersonBradley Jolly21:30, 7 SEP 2018NewsFairfield got into her vehicle despite drinking heavily in Lancashire "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA drink driver who crashed into a parked car after a boozy night out has lost her dream job.  Megan Fairfield, 22, was more than twice the legal drink driving limit when she smashed her red Audi into the vehicle just 200 yards into her journey.  A court heard she had been celebrating her last shift as a care assistant with colleagues when she decided to drive the 500-yard trip home on August 1.  And now she cannot take her dream job caring for young children in the community as she's now lost her driving licence, Rossendale Free Press says.  Fairfield admitted drink driving and was given a fine and costs totalling &pound299 and disqualified from driving for 40 months, reduced by 40 weeks if she completes a drink driving course. Burnley Magistrates Court heard she had previously been disqualified in March 2016 for 17 months for the same offence.  Charlotte Crane, prosecuting, said: He [the owner of the parked car] went outside and was approached by Miss Fairfield who initially claimed that she needed assistance because her friends had run off. He called the police and they arrived. She then changed her story and accepted driving the Audi and made comments that she had been to a leaving do, had been done for drink driving before and apologised for her behaviour. The defendant, from Helmshore, near Blackburn, Lancs., provided a breathalyser reading of 78mg in 100ml of breath. The legal limit is 35mg. But her lawyer said she has been extremely remorseful since the smash.

title: fortnite blamed after online games
story: NewsFortnite, pornography and gambling blamed in 200 divorce cases this yearExperts from Divorce-online say internet gaming can be as dangerous for relationships as drug addictionsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMatt StrudwickDave Burke21:13, 7 SEP 2018Updated21:20, 7 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/incoming/video/fortnite-battle-royale-gameplay-trailer-12192808,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFortnite has been blamed after online games were cited as the reason in 200 divorces this year. The shoot-'em-up game is played by millions around the world - but could prove as damaging to relationships as drug addictions. That's according to bosses at Divorce-online, who say they have noticed a dramatic spike in the number of cases where online gaming causes couples to split up. A spokesman for the company said: Addiction to drugs, alcohol and gambling are have often been cited as reasons for relationship breakdown but the dawn of the digital revolution has introduced new addictions. These now include online pornography, online gaming, and social media, so it is no surprise to us that more and more people are having relationship problems because of our digital addictions. This equates to roughly 5% of the 4,665 petitions we have handled since the beginning of the year and as one of the largest filers of divorce petitions in the UK, is a pretty good indicator. Has your relationship hit the rocks because of Fortnite? Email webnews@trinitymirror   The game is a survival shooter, which has been downloaded more than 100 million times and been endorsed by stars such as footballer Dele Alli and rapper Drake. It sees up to 100 players play against each other in a iety of game modes and is free to play. It is hugely popular with children and teenagers because it can be played on mobile phones but it appears the highly addictive game is not only affecting youngsters. Fortnite's most popular format is the BattleRoyale which sees 100 players fight each other on an island until one is left standing.  The game is available on mobiles and consoles including Xbox One and PlayStation 4, as well as PC and Mac. Earlier this week  reported how a disabled mother said she was left cash-strapped by her 10-year-old son spent who thousands on Fortnite. Single mum-of-two Cleo Duckett, 46, said she discovered her bank account had just &pound8 left in it on Friday night. Cleo, from Cefn Glas in Bridgend and on benefits as she suffers from polio and is on a wheelchair, said she has had to dig funds out of her son's savings pot in order to make until her next benefit payment on September 6.

story: NewsGreggs opens first branch in Cornwall - and the locals are up in armsLocals in the county - most famed for the Cornish Pasty - are up in arms over the shopShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAdam Aspinall16:36, 7 SEP 2018Updated16:45, 7 SEP 2018NewsThe new Greggs bakery which has opened at the Saltash service station in Cornwall "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA war of words has broken out after Greggs opened its first branch - in Cornwall. Locals in the county - most famed for the Cornish Pasty - are up in arms over the shop. The store has been built just off the A38 in Saltash on the Devon Cornwall border. Locals say it opened to ''no fanfare' in the last two weeks but it still doesn't appear on Greggs' website store locator section. Greggs's classic menu does contain a beef pasty - crimped the Devon way along the top - but is not currently on sale in the new branch. There are 1,747 Greggs in the UK with 30 in Manchester, 29 in Newcastle and 26 in Cardiff. Greggs has so far never ventured into the the Cornish Pasty's homeland - until now.  It is understood that Greggs, which has had several stores in neighbouring Devon for many years has never sold pasties in the Westcountry as it did not want to create a pasty war. Greggs confirmed the store had opened in July, although there had been no publicity around it and it was still not visible on the store locator online. But renowned bakers in Cornwall said they had faith that locals will always pick a traditional pasty instead of any imitations. Marion Symonds, 51, owner of Portreath Bakery and Made Marion Gluten Free and a long time campaigner of the traditional Cornish pasty, said: I would have thought they would sell whatever they sell in their normal stores. If they sell pasties in their other shops why wouldn't they sell them in pasty world? I believe that Cornish people who have had Cornish pasties with traditional ingredients will always go to a Cornish bakery.

story: NewsIncredible gesture by three pupils who saw a boy crying on the bus after his first day at secondary schoolThe 11-year-old had got on the wrong bus, and was getting further and further from his Liverpool home when the trio stepped inShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKate Mcmullin20:20, 7 SEP 2018Updated21:00, 7 SEP 2018NewsDylan Robson, a pupil at Holy Family Catholic High School in Liverpool, helped another student who got lost "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum says her faith in humanity has been restored after three schoolboys came to the aid of a crying and lost Year 7 pupil. title: lawyer reveals loophole drivers avoid
story: NewsLawyer reveals loophole for drivers to avoid speeding ticket and it's 'the only way to have case thrown out'There are "practically no defences" a driver can offer when they end up in court for speeding, a legal expert has revealedShare&nbspByJenny Kirkham10:32, 7 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/what-penalties-speeding-uk-13105413,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDavid Beckham is set to fight a speeding charge in a case that has put a spotlight on fixed penalty tickets and how drivers try to wiggle out of one. The former footballer, accused of driving a Bentley at 59mph in a 40mph zone in London, will try to have the case thrown out on a technicality, arguing that the notice didn't arrive within the statutory 14-day window. There are practically no defences in court for driving over the speed limit, a legal expert has told the Liverpool Echo. But a driver can have the charge dismissed if they can prove that the notice arrived too late, like Beckham is attempting to do, said Phoebe Callender, legal adviser at DAS Law.  Here, Ms Callender explains the rules surrounding a notice of intended prosecution and what happens if one is delivered too late to a vehicle's registered keeper. What are the rules surrounding the notification of a fine? When you receive a speeding fine, the first notification you will receive is called a notice of intended prosecution  which is where you need to inform the police who was driving at the time under Section 172 of the Road Traffic Act 1998. This notice should be sent to the registered keeper within 14 days of when the speeding offence took place. If you don’t send the police the driver’s details within the time they state, then you can face up to six penalty points and a fine which is usually &pound100. After this you will be sent notification of whether they will be offering you points and a fine a speed awareness course or if it will progress to a court summons. Can I have a fine dismissed if it was delivered ‘late’?  Under the Road Traffic Act 1998, the NIP has to be sent to the registered keeper within 14 days of the speeding offence. If when you receive the NIP it is dated more than 14 days after the offence took place, then you should send it back to the process office and reject it as it is out of time. If you are not the registered keeper of the car and you receive the NIP past 14 days, you have to check to see if they sent it to the registered keeper within the time period. If it has been, then it won’t be classed as late. If you fail to receive a NIP and only receive a court summons, then you can have a defence to the speeding offence and any subsequent prosecution that takes place. How do I challenge a speeding fine? It is very difficult to challenge a speeding fine as there are practically no defences to why a person was driving over the speed limit, even if you believe it’s not fair. You may be able to challenge it if the notice was incorrect e.g. the date, time, location of the speeding offence. However, spelling mistakes or minor mistakes like the colour of a vehicle etc. will not be accepted. Challenging the evidence of the camera itself can be also tricky as unless you have evidence that the camera is faulty then it is unlikely that you will be able to challenge your speeding fine successfully. Should I use a lawyer/barrister to handle my case or can I do it myself?

title: mum group men carry sofa
story: NewsHouse of Fraser: Furious mum whose sofa never arrived rounds up 'strong lads' and CARRIES it out of storeFiona Boston, 52, paid for the sofa in cash at the Darlington store but it was never delivered - she says: "It’s what you call British justice"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDavid HuntleyElaine McCahill12:46, 7 SEP 2018Updated15:37, 7 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/its-british-justice-mum-strong-13207293,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA furious mum whose dream House of Fraser sofa never arrived rounded up a bunch of strong lads and carried it out of the store. Fiona Boston, from Stockton, County Durham, paid for the sofa in cash at the Darlington store after deciding it was a perfect fit for her home. However, she says it was never delivered after the chain went into administration. Speaking to Teesside Live, the 52-year-old claimed she got no help from staff, so decided to take matters into her own hands. She and some friends marched into the shop, dismantled the sofa in the showroom and walked out the front door with it.  Fiona said: “On July 26 I bought the sofa and chair. I’d had my eye on it for a couple of years, it was a perfect fit for my home. “I paid in cash and three days later I went back to buy some extras on my debit card which cost &pound715.” However, the delivery date for Fiona’s purchases reportedly kept being pushed back. She went back to the store on several occasions to ask when she would get them and to check the sofa was still there. “My husband Alan had an aneurysm last year and it’s taking him a while to get back to full health, but he’d been sitting on deck chairs at home as we were still waiting, she said.  He deserved to be comfortable. I kept asking the manager and staff but they were saying everything was out of their hands.” But then House of Fraser went into administration and Fiona say she lost her money, along with the sofa. She said: “They told me I would be put on a list of creditors and to wait to get my money back. I knew that the chances were I wouldn’t be getting it back. “They even told me I could take finance out on the sofa - but I refused to pay for it twice.” On September 1, Fiona decided to go into the store and take the sofa herself. She said: “I got some of my family together, some strong lads and a van from Scott Bros in Haverton Hill, and decided to go to the store late in the afternoon when it was quite empty.  “We went up to the second floor, took the sofa apart and walked right out the front door. No one batted an eyelid.” Staff quickly surrounded the vehicle as soon as they loaded the sofa into the van. Fiona, who works as a market trader, claimed: “They told me that they’d call the police as it was theft. I said I’d paid for it and had a receipt.” She drove off but was soon pulled over by the police where she explained what happened. “I showed him my receipt and that it was rightfully mine, she said. “He wasn’t happy but called his inspector who said it was a civil matter and to let us drive off. “So we did. It’s what you call British justice.”

title: odd highway code loophole driving
story: AdvertorialOdd Highway Code loophole about driving a car in the dark is leaving motorists baffledBizarre rule applies in brightly-lit 30mph zones - but there's a catchShare&nbspByDave Masters09:48, 4 SEP 2018Updated09:19, 6 SEP 2018AdvertorialMost motorists won't have heard of this"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs the weather changes, there are a few things drivers need to know about their cars and driving. The law on lights is simple enough: you must use car headlights from half an hour after sunset until half an hour before sunrise. But there is a surprising exception to this rule. If you're travelling under 30mph in a brightly-lit area, you don't legally have to have them on - though you do still need your sidelights. It's an odd quirk of the law, but is it recommended? It's generally agreed that using dipped headlights at night is always the best option - making you more visible to other road users as well as improving your view of the road ahead. But if you do choose to use just your sidelights, make sure you don't fall foul of the rules - or you risk a &pound50 fine. Not a bright idea. Make sure you know the rules  It's absolutely crucial that, at all times of the year, your car has a full set of working lights.  As well as an MOT failure, driving with a faulty or damaged light could mean a fixed penalty notice, or three points on the driving licence plus a bigger fine if it goes to court .   Since 2011, it's also been a legal requirement for all new cars sold in the EU to have daytime running lights . The new UK MOT rules mean that cars registered after March 2018 will need to have these working to pass the test.  Research has shown that DRLs are likely to reduce multiple vehicle daytime accidents and fatalities by up to 6% once all vehicles are equipped.   If you don't have DRLs on your car, then it's acceptable to leave your sidelights on all the time. Many cars will automatically turn sidelights on if they have an auto mode for lights, they will also switch to dipped lights when its sensor feels it's dark enough. The law states that you need your dipped headlights on between sunset and sunrise - but there's no harm turning them on early to improve your visibility to other road users. Check your lights regularly  The best way to do this is with a friend who can confirm that the reverse and brake lights are all working. Alternatively, you can use a reflective surface like a garage door. You can check hazard/indicator lights yourself as well as the running lights and dipped/main beam settings. If you notice a bulb isn't working, then pop to Halfords - they will select and fit replacement bulbs to your car for a small fee, and there's no need to book beforehand.  For a more comprehensive check that everything is working as it should, make an appointment online or in-store for a Free Car Check . As well as a bulb check, they'll also check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. They'll even give you a free screenwash top-up!  Don't be dazzled  As nights get earlier we all have to contend with headlights dazzling us. Remember that most rearview mirrors these days offer protection from bright lights from behind. On newer cars you'll often have an auto-dimming mirror - which means you just let it protect you from being distracted by overly-bright lights. If you find yourself struggling to see, you'll notice an off switch to disable the feature. On older cars it's common that your rear view mirror will have a small mechanical switch underneath it. Flip that and the mirror will change angle, without adjusting the view you see. This is used to stop you from being dazzled in the same way a modern electric system works.  If your car has an old manual mirror then why not upgrade to an EchoMaster Dynamic Mirror and Reversing Camera Kit  for &pound149. A reversing camera is fitted behind your number plate by a bracket. This rearview mirror also auto-dims, perfect for autumn driving! Halfords will also fit the whole system for &pound75.  Keep your car clean  A dirty car looks bad, but it might also get you in to trouble. The law states that your number plate needs to be clean and visible at all times. You also need to make sure that brake lights are clean and clearly visible.  As well as using a good car cleaner you should also make sure your windscreen and lights are clean. Use a specialist glass cleaning product like Autoglym Car Glass Polish , &pound8. You can pair that with the Demon Car Valet Pack  - priced &pound24.50  to get every part of your car shiny as new.

title: ordinary peoples wages stagnate politicians
story: NewsopinionAs ordinary people's wages stagnate, politicians are more than ever in awe of the greedy bankersTheir recklessness may have ruined millions of lives but not one senior banker has been jailed in the UKShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBrian Reade18:51, 7 SEP 2018NewsopinionGreedy bankers are still getting eye-watering bonuses post-crash "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt's funny how we all celebrate big anniversaries in different ways.  Take Boris Johnson , who’s decided in his 25th wedding anniversary year to let it be known his marriage is dead, so when he makes a play for the Tory leadership his leg-over longings won’t count against him.   Then there’s Tony Blair , who took time out from lobbying for a gas &shypipeline on behalf of his autocratic Azerbaijani paymasters, to give an important interview with the BBC.  As we hit the 10th anniversary of the banking crash, was he finally going to admit that his government’s lax &shyregulation and its attitude of being “intensely relaxed” about the rich getting richer, helped cause the worst depression since the 1920s? Maybe an apology, or an attack on The Big Swinging Dicks who caused it, then were allowed to speed past the rest of us in shiny red Lamborghinis while we sat in clapped-out Ladas in the slow lane? No. Just an attack on a Labour Party leadership that is proposing policies that would rein in the City-led greed that holds our country back. This past decade, while banks have grown bigger, richer and more untouchable on taxpayer subsidies, ordinary people have been punished with a brutal austerity programme which has seen their wages stagnate and personal debt rocket. Their recklessness may have ruined millions of lives but not one senior banker has been jailed in the UK or one judge-led inquiry into their countless acts of criminality set up.  Today our banking system has more capital behind it than it has done for a century yet the wider economy has suffered the lowest decade for growth since Victorian times. They’re still Masters of The Universe, enjoying eye-watering pay, bonuses and payoffs, and the subservient politicians who encouraged their reckless greed a decade ago are even more in awe of them. It’s as though the political class has deliberately refused to learn anything from that seismic crash. The mantra from on high is still that without these financial “wealth creators” our public services would start collapsing. Even though, like that dated economic model itself, they already have.

title: storm florence could batter uk
story: NewsStorm Florence could batter UK with 65mph gales if path steers away from USMet Office forecasters say Britain is braced for 'gales and heavy rain' as the course of Storm Florence may alterShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly22:13, 7 SEP 2018NewsThese forecast images suggest Storm Florence may in fact be heading towards Europe "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailViolent remnants of Storm Florence may lash 65mph gales and downpours across the UK, these startling computer model images show. The tropical blast is currently swirling across the Atlantic towards the US and it's feared it may be upgraded to a hurricane by the time it reaches the country.  But new digital graphics created by meteorologists measuring the course of Storm Florence show it may veer away from the US and into Europe's - and the UK's - path by the middle of the month.   Forecasters say it's effects won't be as devastating but will batter the country with 65mph gusts and heavy rain.  Lee Robertson, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service , assessed the image of the new jet-stream and called it still a possibility.   And Dr Claire Kennedy-Edwards, a Weather Channel meteorologist, said: Others [forecast models] show the storm re-curving around the subtropical ridge as the remnants of Florence get entrained into the jet stream.  Latest model runs show a iety of downstream effects for western Europe. However some forecast models are favouring a more westward track for Tropical Storm Florence, which could impact north-eastern areas of the US.   The Met Office in the UK does fear some extremely unsettled weather from around September 15 but cannot confirm if this as a result of Storm Florence.  It says: Occasional spells of more unsettled weather are likely, these mainly in the northwest where there is a risk of gales and heavy rain at times, and with the rain perhaps occasionally spreading across other areas.

title: teenage girl sent home school
story: NewsTeenage girl sent home from school because trousers mum bought from Asda were 'too tight'Scarlett O'Donoghue, 14, was one of around 40 pupils given their marching orders or put into isolation at Forge Valley School in SheffieldShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly20:29, 7 SEP 2018Updated21:53, 7 SEP 2018NewsScarlett O'Donoghue, 14, in the skirt deemed 'too tight' by her Sheffield school "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A teenage girl was sent home on the second day of the new school term after teachers insisted her trousers from Asda were too tight, her mum claims.   Some 40 pupils from Forge Valley School in Malin Bridge, Sheffield, were given their marching orders or put into isolation on Thursday for breaking the zero tolerance uniform rules.  Scarlett O'Donoghue, 14, was pulled to one side by a teacher and told to change her trousers - for which mum Claire paid &pound27 for three pairs from the Asda school range - or go home.  And staff rang her furious mum Claire, 42, to tell her Scarlett was not allowed in class. She said: Scarlett was so excited about starting her GCSEs - I was livid. We've not got a lot of money and Scarlett knows we've not got &pound50 to spend on an outfit she can't wear. What I cannot get over is what right does one teacher have to say my child's trousers are too tight?  Claire forking out &pound51 on three pairs of trousers and three skirts but teachers said the clothing was unacceptably tight. The mum-to-two, who runs a glazing firm with husband Michael, 51, added: Scarlett thinks she's too fat like a lot of teenage girls - for someone in authority to 'say your clothes are too tight' is disgusting. A lot of girls also have issues about their weight and their body image. So if you have an adult telling you the skirt is too tight it's going to hugely harm your self-esteem. What is that saying to teenage girls about their self-confidence when they are already worried about their weight. They're sexualising young girls who should be allowed to wear whatever they want to wear.  Scarlett has been very upset and angry about the whole thing. We spent over &pound50 on new school uniforms and the school are not going to give me that back. It was the second time Scarlett had been pulled up over uniform after she arrived in school the previous day wearing a skirt which staff also said was unacceptably tight. An online petition has been signed by more than 500 parents, angry with the uniform policy. But Dale Barrowclough, headteacher at the school, said: We have the uniform policy because it promotes a professional ethos in the school and it allows pupils who can't afford branded clothes to avoid bullying. This is something that was raised by parents and which is why they wanted the uniform policy and it would be unfair to change it now. I'm not prepared to relax our high standards. It's why Forge Valley is oversubscribed and we could not say that when the school opened. Parents are always given adequate warning about next year's uniform in my end of summer term letter which says that full uniform must be worn for the start of September. Mr Barrowclough said a small number of pupils were sent home from school on Wednesday but said he could empathise with parents over buying uniforms.

title: teenage girl who masterminded shocking
story: NewsTeenager who masterminded shocking 2am knife attack on her ex-boyfriend and new partner is jailedAnna Dickinson, 18, was sentenced to 32 months in a young offenders institution over the attack on ex-boyfriend Tyrone Baines, also 18, and his new loverShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy WalkerElaine McCahill13:58, 7 SEP 2018Updated17:53, 7 SEP 2018NewsAnna Dickinson masterminded a shocking 2am knife attack on her ex-boyfriend and his new lover  Ltd"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenager who masterminded a shocking 2am knife attack on her ex-boyfriend and his new lover after discovering they were having a romance was jailed today. Jealous college student Anna Dickinson, 18, recruited two friends to help her launch a savage assault on Tyrone Baines, also 18, in the dead of night after she learnt he was dating another girl. After making threats to ‘'bang’' and ‘'stab’' his new girlfriend, Dickinson and her accomplices burst into 18-year old Mr Baines' home in Lancaster whilst the couple were in bed together. The three swarmed around Mr Baines and left him with three stab wounds to the back and a bite mark. Dickinson and her best friend Kathryn Stanley, 18, then burst into his bedroom where the unnamed girl, 17, was lying in bed naked. Stanley jumped on top of his girlfriend, punched her to the head and held her arms to stop her defending herself as Dickinson stabbed at her and tried to cut her hair off as a way of ''degrading'' her.  The assault only ended when Stanley said: “I didn’t think you were going to stab her.''  Baines and his girlfriend later received stitches for the several serious lacerations and stab wounds but made a miraculous recovery.  In a statement the girl said she feared she would be killed and added: “Since the incident I have struggled with my anxiety and stress due to what happened when I was stabbed by Anna. “I am so scared of them and I will go out of my way to never be see them again. I struggle day to day now to leave the house without somebody. What they did to me will stay with me for the rest of my life and I will always have the scars on my back. “I have started counselling and I am trying to deal with how to trust people again in my life. I am scared and fearful of them. She was contacting my friends and calling me a liar and trying to intimidate me.” At Preston Crown Court Dickinson, Stanley and Jordan Gardner, 18, all of Lancaster admitted causing grievous bodily harm with intent and unlawful wounding. Dickinson and Stanley were locked up for 32 months in a young offenders institution and Gardner a close friend of Tyrone was detained for 21 months.  As sentences were passed fighting broke out between loved ones of the families.  The incident took place on February 19 after Tyrone split up with Dickinson following a four month fling and began dating the other girl. Prosecutor Raymond Smith said: “Dickinson and the girl had been friends and known each other for some years.  But the friendship between the two of them deteriorated to the point Dickinson sent messages via social media threatening to “bang” and “stab” her. That day Dickinson had sent messages to Tyrone asking if his girlfriend was at home. ''Some time later Tyrone and his partner went to bed and fell asleep.  Two hours later, Tyrone was woken up by Gardner shouting to be let in. Tyrone got out of bed partially dressed and went downstairs and heard Gardner trying to get in through the living room window. “Tyrone opened the door and Gardner came into the house running upstairs, whilst Dickinson and Stanley also came into the house and came running upstairs.  Dickinson was carrying a knife and Tyrone recognised it as being from the kitchen. In light of the previous threats Tyrone was scared for his girlfriend and he tried to hold the bedroom door shut.  “But Dickinson was stabbing at him trying to get around him. Tyrone was trying to reason with the two women. Tyrone was being stabbed many times by Dickinson. Eventually he failed to stop them gaining entry to the bedroom and witnessed the attack on his partner. “By this stage Gardner was leaving and had left the house. Tyrone had sustained stab wounds to the neck and back and had cuts to the back and bruises to his neck where Dickinson had tried to bite him when she was trying to get past him. “The female victim could see that Tyrone was struggling with the two women and she could see a knife in Dickinson's hand.  Stanley ran into the room and jumped on top of her and punched her to the head and body. She held her wrists making it difficult for her to defend herself. “She remembers the blade of the knife being held to her throat and being stabbed on her arm by Dickinson. She then remembers Stanley shouting: “I didn’t think you were going to stab her.” Tyrone had gone to get the two women out of the bedroom when the female noticed she was bleeding from many wounds.  In her statement she said she was frightened and thought she was going to be killed.  The girl suffered stab wounds to her arms neck and face plus wounds to her left upper back and chest.  Tyrone had wounds to his back and chest.  After the attack Dickinson called her mother requesting a lift and made a telephone call at 4am to tell a friend what she had done. Mr Smith added: “Dickinson played a leading role in the group attack. It is aggravated by the location and time of the offence, this was in the victim’s bedroom when she was naked and asleep.'' Dickinson's lawyer Amanda Hamilton said: “She is accepting of what happened and has deep regrets and hurt for the two people who suffered significant wounds.  She was in a relationship with Tyrone, he was the man she loved and there was a desperate nature of the relationship, it was a difficult one. She wishes she didn’t attend Tyrone’s house in that night. “She accepts she went to the house and took a weapon with her but she didn’t make threats to use the weapon. She wants to face up to and understand what happened that night. She wants the victims to know how truly sorry she is.   “She has done a lot of volunteer work with animals, she enjoys working with cats and dogs . She has an extremely supportive family.  She doesn’t recall sending these messages and they have disappeared from social media, but as the prosecution witnesses are saying they received them, she accepts that. Since her arrest she has found a group of friends who support her.”  Robert Elias for Stanley, said: “She did not have a quarrel, she had not been scorned but she was holding Dickinson's hand. She had no knowledge of her friend picking up the knife. This wasn’t premeditated, she didn’t knew it was going to happen. “Once the momentum began she took part. She climbed by that young lady, struck her, then unknowing there was a knife she offered the responsibility and prospect of matters getting worse. She was horrified, she was shouting about the need for it to happen.  “Since the incident she has moved counties. She presents to be quite an intelligent young woman and is frustrated with herself for having got in this situation, she doesn’t blame Miss Dickinson, she thinks she should have seen through the anger before there was this confrontation. “ She was there for other reasons, she wanted to show loyalty and to help her friend. She is wanting to make a go of things.” Sentencing Judge Heather Lloyd said: “Tyrone Baines and the female victim began to get close and it was clear you did not like the fact they were together. It is clear from the messages you were threatening to stab his girlfriend and on that night that is precisely what you did.

title: time capsule home abandoned owner
story: NewsOrdinary-looking three-bedroom house hides some incredible 'time capsule' secrets insideThe modest three-bedroom semi - built in 1937 - looks like the rest of the suburban street from the outside but is a time capsule insideShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNathan Sandhu17:03, 7 SEP 2018Updated20:31, 7 SEP 2018NewsAaron Whiteside steps back into the 1930s at this property "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEverytime Aaron Whiteside goes through his front door he steps back into the 1930s - after transforming his home into one for the pre-war era. Aaron, 36, has dreamt of living in a 1930s' home complete with authentic gadgets and furniture from the era ever since he was a five-year-old boy. He is the proud owner of a modest three-bedroom semi - built in 1937 - looks like the rest of the suburban street from the outside but is a time capsule inside. Everything inside is from a bygone era, including the rare wallpaper, coal fires and electric cooker which was one of the first of its kind. Aaron recalls browsing junk shops aged five, picking up an old radiogram, hoover, mincers and gas lamps during trips with his grandmother's sister. Since then, he has slowly become enamoured with the decade's style and way of life. He bought his current home in Blackpool, Lancs., for &pound87,000 in 2007 after it had stood empty for nearly a decade.  The enthusiast has worked tirelessly to transform the house - installing German wallpaper which was buried in a time capsule in the 1930s and cost Aaron &pound100 a roll. He sleeps in a vintage bed, has a GEC cooker, doesn't own a television or fridge and still uses a laundry mangle. Not content with just looking like it's in the 1930s, the house also runs like a pre-war one would have, heated by four coal fires and without double glazing windows. He said: From the age of five I always liked the music, a lot of people think I've been here before. My grandmother's sister would take me round junk shops and I collected a lot of gramophones.  The first ever item I bought was an old radiogram from the 1950s and an old hoover, as well old mincers and gas lamps. It's all bits like that as to how it all started and it's got a bit out of hand since. I've tried to make sure all the items in the house are originals, rather than being replicas. My pride of joy is an HMV state of the art gramophone from 1937. It came from an old house down south where bits and pieces were being sold off, and a friend of a friend told me about it. Anyone that comes to the house absolutely love it, I'm not saying they would want to live in it but I've not really had any bad feedback. Aaron, who has no children, loves 1930s vocalists including Judy Garland, Jessie Matthews and Billie Holiday and even watches silent films.  When at home, he wears vintage clothes, sports a slick back undercut hairstyle and bearded finish and eats a 1930s diet - including cooking foods in beef dripping. The house was built in 1937 so this house always had a toilet, he added. It runs on coal so I have to lit the fire in the backroom for hot water. If I buy a rib of beef and have friends for tea I will cook it the old fashioned way, I don't use oil.  The washing machine I've got is a Hotpoint electric one with a mangle. The hoover is a 1934 electric hoover senior which I have been using since I was kid. The wall masks I collected are hard to come by, they are by an artist called John Douglas. I have the King up on the wall and there are thirties art decor original pictures. There is the Victorian organ in there as well as a great big Edwardian sideboard. The kitchen has got the original tiles and sink and cupboards. It's pretty bog standard to how it was when it was built. The hallway is pretty much as it was apart from it's got new wallpaper, it's an old reprint. The items I have sort of go up to the 1940s. Even at the end of the war, you were still living in the thirties because there was no production.

title: woman whose baby decapitated womb
story: NewsWoman whose baby was decapitated in womb felt "loud pop" as doctor pulled on infant's legsLaura Gallazzi claims the medic "butchered" her son and hid the truth from her when she gave her the devastating news that her baby boy Steven was deadShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitching08:01, 7 SEP 2018Updated08:33, 7 SEP 2018NewsDr Vaishnavy Laxman arrives for a tribunal hearing in May "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mother whose baby was accidentally decapitated by a doctor as she gave birth says she felt a loud pop before chaos and panic swept through the delivery room.  Laura Gallazzi claims the medic butchered her son and hid the truth from her when she gave her the devastating news that her baby didn't make it. The 34-year-old's premature son, Steven, was trapped in the breech position and, instead of performing an emergency Caesarean section, Dr Vaishnavy Laxman tugged on his legs in a bid to get him out. The infant's head broke off in the womb and had to be recovered later by two doctors who carried out a C-section.   Ms Gallazzi, who was just 25 weeks pregnant when she went into labour, has spoken out for the first time about her son's death at Ninewells Hospital in Dundee and how she has been left with post-traumatic stress disorder.   She told the Sun that she puts the blame squarely on Dr Laxman, who has been cleared to continue practising, and she believes she was fooled into initially forgiving her.  Ms Gallazzi, who keeps her son's ashes in a teddy bear and has outlines of his hands and feet tattooed on her arm, said: She butchered my son. How could this happen in this day and age? She had been rushed straight into theatre after arriving at the hospital, where medics discovered that she had a prolapsed umbilical cord, which happens when the cord drops through the open cervix into the vagina ahead of the baby.  The cord can become trapped against the baby's body during delivery. Ms Gallazzi said she was told to push and, even though it felt completely wrong and she thought she would have a C-section, she did as Dr Laxman asked. She was only two to three centimetres dilated - less than the NHS guidelines of 10cm for a natural birth - and the doctor had twice cut her cervix. Dr Laxman, who was nearing the end of a 24-hour shift, tried a natural delivery instead of a C-section as the baby arrived on March 16, 2014. Ms Gallazzi said she felt the doctor pull on Steven's legs as other medics pushed down on her stomach. She said she begged Dr Laxman to stop because she was in so much pain, and tried to crawl away from her.  She said: “I could feel something between my legs and then all of a sudden I felt a massive, loud pop. I thought I’d done it. I thought he was out. “But then I felt a sense of chaos and panic throughout the room and I was being told to push again. Then I was told I was being put to sleep and the lights went out.” After her son died during birth, she woke up as she recovered in a room for mothers who have suffered loss in pregnancy. Her sister Louise was in tears and Dr Laxman soon came in and delivered the devastating news that Steven had died. Ms Gallazzi assumed the baby died because he was premature and claims she didn't know that his he had been decapitated. She said Dr Laxman sat down next to her on the hospital bed and told her that Steven had died.

title: abby hernandez reveals tactics used
story: NewsAbby Hernandez reveals 'tactics' she used to stay alive during nine month kidnap ordeal as she was torturedAbby Hernandez was abducted after leaving school on October 9, 2013, sparking a desperate search that ended when she walked into her family's home nine months laterShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitchingAmber Hicks22:56, 7 SEP 2018Updated22:58, 7 SEP 2018NewsAbby Hernandez was 14 when she was abducted"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKidnap victim Abby Hernandez has revealed how she stayed alive during the nine month ordeal in which she was sexually assaulted and tortured. The teen, who was abducted on her way home from school, said her survival instincts kicked in and she realised she had to work with the man holding her captive.  I said [to him], ‘I don’t judge you for this. If you let me go, I won’t tell anybody about this,’” Abby recalled during an interview with ABC News .  However her initial attempts to negotiate with her sick abductor proved unsuccessful and for nine months he forced her to wear a dog shock collar and call him Master.  Twisted Nate Kibby inflicted abuse on her daily, but she used the 'power of prayer' to keep her hope alive. She added: “I remember I never said ‘amen’ in my mind. I never wanted to end my prayers because I didn't want God to leave me. “I just really wanted to live.” One of the other tactics Ms Hernandez used was to think strategically and establish a bond with her captor. She said: “I told him, ‘Look, you don't seem like a bad person. Like, everybody makes mistakes… If you let me go, I won't tell anybody about this.’”  Ms Hernandez, then 14, was hidden away in a storage container where she was drugged, repeatedly raped and psychologically tortured before finally being released. She was abducted after leaving school on October 9, 2013, sparking a desperate search that ended when she walked into her family's home nine months later. For the first time, Ms Hernandez, 19, has described her ordeal in detail and told how she is coping years on from the abduction in the US town of Conway, New Hampshire.  In an exclusive interview, she told the ABC News programme 20/20 that Kibby put a dog shock collar on her to stop her from screaming and alerting people nearby.   He also told her to call him Master and claimed that he had rigged the storage container on his property in Gorham - about 30 miles from where he abducted the girl - to erupt in flames if she tried to escape or if someone tried to save her. Ms Hernandez said: “He said, ‘You know, I’m thinking of finding something a little more humane for you to keep you quiet. “He said, ‘I’m thinking of a shock collar’, you know, like dogs wear. “I remember he put it on me and he told me, ‘OK, try and scream’. I just slowly started raising my voice and then it shocked me. “He was like, ‘OK, now you know what it feels like’.”  She added: “He told me call me ‘Master’.” Kibby, now 37, claimed he had rigged the storage container's door with wires and screws, telling Ms Hernandez that she would die if someone tried to rescue her. She told ABC News correspondent Deborah Roberts: “He told me that he tripped the door so that if for any reason it was busted open it would catch on fire. “If somebody kicked open the door I would go up in flames, basically.” She thought Kibby was watching her remotely because a surveillance camera was always blinking.  Ms Hernandez said she used psychological strategies to stay alive, including bonding with Kibby. She didn't know his name until she found it inside a cookbook he had given her while she was being held. Kibby had kidnapped her after offering her a ride home, and pulled out a gun and threatened to shoot her when she tried to get out of his car. She didn't know him but accepted the ride because her feet were sore and blistered.

story: NewsTunisia's lost lavish hotels abandoned by tourists after 2015 terror attackStill laid out in all their grandeur, the hotel's white lobbies and dining halls remain laden with chairs, tables and sofas for guestsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJosh Saunders16:59, 7 SEP 2018Updated17:04, 7 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/tunisias-lost-lavish-hotels-were-13208749,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTunisia's hotels once a top tourist destination now lay abandoned after the terror attacks in 2015. The decline in tourism in Tunisia followed a spate of terror attacks in 2015, where 71 people were killed in three incidents. The worst of that year occurred in June, when 38 foreign tourists, including 30 British nationals, were killed in an attack on Port El Kantaoui near Sousse. Eerie footage shows hotels in Djerba, which were also hit hard by the decline in tourism. Still laid out in all their grandeur, the white lobbies and dining halls remain laden with chairs, tables and sofas for guests. Stunning chandeliers hang from the ceilings and facilities, from a fully-equipped bar to massage tables and spa rooms, remain intact apart from a heavy coating of dust. Outside, the magnificent Moorish-design courtyards remain impressive yet overgrown in their abandonment, with green pond-like liquid lying in the pools, Jacuzzis and water features. A state of emergency was first declared in Tunisia three years ago.  Advice from the UK Government states: Terrorists are very likely to try to carry out attacks in Tunisia, listing eight extremist activities. Urban explorer Bob Thissen, from Heerlen, The Netherlands, visited the sites after the country was declared a no-fly zone, and where some of the hotels closed as early as 2008. Bob said: It was crazy to walk alone in such big resorts where thousands of tourists used to spend their holidays. It was so silent. It's like a lost paradise. The pools have dirty green water, are half filled with sand and vegetation, or just the salt is left inside the saltwater pools. The normally perfect swept paths are now full of sand and covered with dead palm leaves. The outdoor animation buildings are falling apart, bars are empty, and the playground equipment appears lonely. All resorts were completely different, from perfect condition to completely ruined. I liked the post-apocalyptic exteriors with the pools the most.  It's crazy that these sized resorts are abandoned. Most resorts have multiple outdoor and indoor pools. It was a big contrast to see these abandoned decaying hotels against the beautiful blue water beaches. The decline in tourism in Tunisia followed a spate of terror attacks in 2015, where 71 people were killed in three incidents. The worst of that year occurred in June, when 38 foreign tourists, including 30 British nationals, were killed in an attack on Port El Kantaoui near Sousse. Bob and his group of 'urbexers' documented the locations for their channel 'Exploring the Unbeaten Path'. He said: I think the area around Sousse was affected more by the decline than in Djerba. I think Djerba already had a hard time in the tourism industry, many hotels were already abandoned before 2015, but after the terrorist attacks it became even worse. I think it's not only abandoned due the attacks but made even worse because of the media and government. In Western Europe there have been many terrorist attacks and those countries remain 'safe' for tourists to visit. After the two terrorist attacks Tunisia was turned into a no-go zone, many airlines didn't fly to Tunisia anymore until recently and it had a huge impact on the tourism industry.
